DEPT INDIAN AFFAIRS OTTAWA ONT

RE SCHOOL BUILDING PAINTING FINISHED SO WORK COMPLETE

DR ALFRED POWERS.

[Handwritten note]

USE OUR DIRECT ALL-CANADA SERVICE TO VANCOUVER, VICTORIA AND BRITISH COLUMBIA POINTS
Sir,

With reference to my telegram of yesterday, in answer to yours of the 23rd inst., and which read as follows:

"Re School contract about ten days more painting to complete under my supervision. Explanatory letter follows."

I beg to say that when the icebreaker arrived at Bersimis, there was still the painting to be done all the material being on the premises, and as Mr Amyot would have had to stay behind and pay very to get back to Ottawa in the winter, travelling up the North Shore, I asked him to be kind enough to look after this painting to be done. So in consequence I delivered him his last certificate, and he passed a contract with the painter for the completion of the painting of the building. With a week to ten days more everything will be completed.

As to the work performed by Mr Amyot, I must say that with my very limited knowledge of construction, I am of the opinion that the work was well done.

The contractor had to do the work under trying conditions at times specially during the last part of October up to the 15th of December, on account of the lateness of the season.

Although, as far as I am concerned, I find that the work is satisfactorily done, it would, it seems to me, relieve me of a lot of responsibility, if either the architect or engineer of the Dept. inspected the building. But as before stated the work under the condition due to the late season could not be better done, according to me.

The final payment could be done, with the understanding that the building is not finally accepted, till the Spring, should the Dept. decide to send the engineer to inspect the work.

Trusting that these explanations will be satisfactory, I am,

Yours truly,

[Signature]

(Alf. Powers, M.D.)
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Dept. Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Having been referred to you by Mr. Sabourin of the Quebec Department about different works which must be done at the Bersimis Hospital on the North Shore Co., Saguenay you would obliged me very much to let me know your views on that point.

I have to fulfilled a contract for the Hudson Bay Co., and I should be able to make the best possible prices for the finishing of those works; because I could make the whole work on the same trip.

It's first about a cesspool building; and for a lighting system installation to both being for the Hospital and for which ones I should be glad to submit you a price upon receipt of a plan or other devices.

Hoping my letter will be favoured, and will make me please to read you soon I remain yours very truly,

RAOUL THIBAULT CONTRACTOR

Sir,

With reference to the New School on the Reserve, I beg to point out that there will be some furniture needed for the living quarters of the Sisters, as follows:

Kitchen. Cook stove. Concerning the cook stove, I must point out that as it is necessary to get every year some fir-wood to the amount of about $70.00 it would probably be better to get an oil stove which would only be used for meals, and a water tank oil-heater. The question of fuel would be thus simplified, but the initial cost would be higher; 2 kitchen chairs, one kitchen cabinet, one kitchen table.

Dining-room. One table and six chairs.

Community-room. One center table and 4 or 5 five assorted chairs.

Four bedrooms. Four single beds, springs and mattresses. Four dressers.

A set of dishes, and miscellaneous cooking utensils which the Sisters will choose when they arrive at the School, and on which I can report further on.

All of the above presupposes that the Dept. will do the furnishing of the School, which is I think the only plausible way to entice the Teachers here as they have no furniture to move in or out.

An early reply on the matter will enable to rush things along, and any suggestions the Dept. might think of will be duly appreciated.

Yours truly,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Dept. Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, April 14th, 1924.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 1st instant, giving a list of the furnishings required for the teachers' living quarters in the new school building on the Bersimis Reserve.

In reply I beg to say that the Department furnishes a reasonable supply of equipment for teachers' living quarters, especially at the time a new building is erected. You may, therefore, arrange for the purchase and delivery of the following, viz:

Kitchen: - A wood burning cook stove of the type and size required. It is considered that there would be a certain element of danger in installing an oil stove, and it is thought that there would be no difficulty in obtaining the quantity of firewood required for fuel if a wood burning stove is obtained. Besides the stove, you may purchase 2 chairs, 1 kitchen cabinet and 1 table.

Dining Room: - 1 table and 6 chairs.

Community Room: - 1 centre table and 6 assorted chairs.

Bedrooms: - 4 single iron beds, with springs and mattresses; 4 dressers.

A set of dishes and a supply of miscellaneous cooking utensils may also be obtained. A list of these should be obtained from the Sisters when they arrive.

Before making any of the above purchases, it will be necessary to obtain competitive prices from a number of dealers in Rimouski, or elsewhere, and the purchase should be made from the firm quoting the lowest price. While articles of a serviceable type should be secured, it is not intended that any elaborate or expensive furniture be supplied. The Department will leave the matter in your hands to obtain the above equipment at the lowest possible cost. Properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded in favour of the merchant from whom you make the purchase. A memo. should accompany the vouchers showing the

A. W. Powers, Esq., M.D.,
Indian Agent,
Bersimis, Que.
names of the firms asked by you for a quotation and the amount quoted.

You should attend to the matter of these purchases and arrange to have them taken to Bersimis at the first opportunity.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Memorandum

Plans and specifications in French and English of the proposed septic tank for the Ber-simis School, which will be occupied this fall, are now completed.

The estimated cost of this tank amounts to $990.00, exclusive of the expenses which will be incurred for the transportation of labour and materials, this factor depending on the distance of transportation, etc.

As it is important that this work be performed before the building is occupied, I would recommend that tenders be invited from contractors in the vicinity of the Reserve, and the general contractor who erected the building.

Sir,

The Sisters have called my attention to the fact that their bedrooms contain no wardrobes, which is almost indispensable. Mr. Raoul Thibault, who is here at present, would undertake to make the above wardrobes (four) in B.C. Fir oiled and varnished and installed for the sum of Seventy dollars.

There is also needed for the classrooms three shelves for clocks, and statues; but as the walls are plaster it would be better to make small pedestals to receive the above so as not to mar the plaster. These pedestal could be made for the price of ten dollars.

Your authority for the above will be awaited for.

Yours truly,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Dept. Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, June 11th, 1924.

Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 5th instant, I beg to inform you that you may arrange to have a wardrobe made and installed in each of the four bedrooms of the Sisters' living quarters at the Bersimis Indian Day School. You may also arrange to have small pedestals on which to place clocks and statues made for the classrooms. The cost of the wardrobes and pedestals should not exceed the price mentioned by you, viz: $70 for the 4 wardrobes and $10 for the pedestals. Properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering the expenditure incurred.

I enclose herewith an account which has been received from Marceau & Fils for furnishings supplied by them for the use of the teachers' living quarters. It is presumed that these were bought by you under authority of official letter of April 14th, last. If these goods have been delivered, you should attach this account to proper voucher forms, certify the same and return to the Department in order that payment can be made.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir,

I beg to enclose herewith vouchers in favor of the Revd. Fathers Eudistes for boarding Sisters St Eugene & St Raphael and another Sister cook for 10 days.

The furniture for the order for their living quarters in the New School were ordered on the 15th of May last and were delayed in transit so that they only landed here in Bersimis on the 4th of June and consequently it was impossible for them to live in the school. Revd Father Labrie who is in charge of the mission at my request consented to Board the Sisters for the ten days mentioned.

Under the circumstances it was impossible to do otherwise, and I trust that you will authorize the payment of attached vouchers.

Yours truly,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir:

A few days ago, the Sisters of the school complained that their water was very bad.

I examined the well where they draw their water. I found that this well was made of timber about 13 years ago, the wood is totally rotten and on the verge of collapse.

From the hygienic point of view it should be condemned; so much so that the children who are going to the school drink that water.

It would be necessary to remedy this state of affairs as soon as possible.

I have personally estimated the cost of the rebuilding of that well, having no one competent to do it.

Ottawa, June 17, 1933.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 9th instant, giving an estimate of the cost of placing the well at the Bersimis Indian Day School in a satisfactory state of repair.

I beg to report that the roof of the school is in bad condition. It leaks in two places, where the roofs of the side wings meet that of the centre portion of the building. Sir:

Mr. Fabien, of this Department, who visited the Bersimis Indian Day School, reports that the roof requires considerable repairs. It leaks in two places, where the roofs of the side wings meet that of the centre portion of the building. Monsieur le Secrétaire,

En faisant le rapport annuel, j'ai fait une remarque au sujet de l'eau, mais j'ai préféré attendre espérant attirer davantage votre attention.

Depuis six ans que je vis ici nous avons marqué d'eau tous les hivers et depuis plus d'un an elle est potable pour ne pas dire, pas du tout.

La boiserie du puits est complètement finie tant elle tant elle est pourrie, le dessus également de sorte qu'il est dangereux de s'aventurer dans les abords, et que par les trous faits dans le bois les petites bêtes peuvent facilement s'y introduire. J'estime beaucoup les crapauds, ces amis des jardiniers, mais je ne les aime pas au point d'en boire le jus comme nous avons fait durant plus de deux mois l'été dernier.

Vu que tout reste toujours au même point après en avoir parlé plusieurs fois à l'Agent je me demande si s'en occupe réellement ou si c'est le Département des Affaires Indiennes qui ne veut pas voter l'argent nécessaire. Je doute fort que l'Agent soit bien zélé pour cette cause surtout après l'avoir vu hier donner ordre de faire une manière de clôture autour du puits laquelle ferait honneur à Messieurs les Inspecteurs du Gouvernement s'ils le voyaient.

Peut-être serait-il bon de profiter de l'occasion des si-
parations que nécessite ce puits pour le faire creuser de quelque pieds pour que l'eau ne manque plus d'ici.
Ce n'est pas toujours agréable avec une soixantaine d'enfants qui fréquentent les classes, de manquer d'eau et de la faire à chaudières chez les voisins qui malgré leur grande charité finissent par trouver cela en las-
sant.
D'autant plus que l'eau ne peut pas être aussi propre à boire chargée par des hommes dont les habits sont sales, les chaudières sont souvent mises par terre pour ouvrir et fermer les portes pendant que les chiens viennent flaire la chaudière quand ils ne sont pas tentés d'y boire.
J'espère que vous prendrez ma requête en considéra-
tion et que vous autoriserez notre Agent à s'en occuper si-
rieusement.
En attendant je demeure votre obligeé,
Pour Sainte-Jeanne, Supérieure.
Mr. A.T. MacKenzie
Secretary of Indian Affairs, Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

When I wrote the annual report, I called your attention to the water. I prefer to wait to show the situation.

For six years that I have been here, we have always had no water every winter and for over a year it has been hardly drinkable.

The wooden walls of the well is completely gone, absolutely rotten, the top in the same way, so that it is dangerous to venture too near it, and through the holes in the planks small animals can easily pass. I like birds that are the friends of gardens but I hate to drink the water they take it, and that is practically what we have done for more than two months.

As we are always remaining at the same point after having spoken many times to the Agent, I am wondering if he is really telling the department what the situation is or if it is the department that does not want to allow the necessary funds for the repairs. I have doubts that the Agent is at all looking this up since he had a fence built around the well, which would be seen with disgust by the Inspector of the Government.

I would be well to profit of the moment of the repairs needed to the well to have it dug a few feet more so that it would not be dry in winter.

It is far from being pleasant with about thirty...
pupils coming to school to be without water and have it carried by the pail from neighbors who in spite of their great charity find this annoying at the end.

So much more that the water can not be as clean to drink, carried by men whose clothes are dirty. The pails are often put down to open the doors and close them when dogs come and lick the pails or drink out of them.

I hope you will take my request into consideration and will authorize your Agent to look this up at once.

In the mean time I remain yours respectfully,

(Signed) Sister Sainte Anne Superior.

Sir,

The water in the well is impure. Absolutely improper for drinking and even for washing.

It is not deep enough; at the present moment, when water is high there is exactly 16 inches of water in that well.

Which means that water is lacking most of the time.

Even if there was sufficient water, we would not be able to use it.

According to the last estimate made today, it would cost about $300.00 to put that well in good condition.

Wood: Cedar, 4" thick, frame, $6.00
Nails, 6 & 8", 7.00
Pipes, 50.00
Labour, 115.00

$232.00

These estimates are approximate. We have not mentioned the rental of the motor pump which will be necessary, to remove the water during the course of the work. I hope I can borrow it from the Fire-Department Association, without any costs; I would only have to pay the two men operating it.

Believe it is useless to give more details, because since the fall of 1933 I have been asking for that well. I shall send copies of letters addressed to you when this is mentioned. There must be also the reports of Mr. Parker, inspector, 1933; and that of Mr. Fabien in 1934; the latter has even had the kindness to come with me to examine that well very closely. I have no doubt he must have mentioned it in his report.
I wish to remark that the construction will be more difficult and more costly in the fall than now on account of the rise of the water.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Agent

You would be very kind if you would inform the Mother Superior that it is not our account of me if the well is not done.

The work can be done by the Indians on condition that a good man, a competent Canadian be appointed to supervise them.

I can look over the work in a general way but I would need a competent man to direct it.

Bersimis, Jan. 3, 1936.

A. F. MacKenzie, Esq.,
Secretary, Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I send you herewith a request made to me by Mother Superior of the school at Bersimis. This request coincides with a similar one made to me verbally by the matron of the hospital.

I sincerely believe that this expenditure should be more warranted than the one for the school. At any rate, I believe that the request is very reasonable and I beg to recommend same.

Three private families, here at Bersimis, have been using the gasoline Connor washing machine; excellent results have been obtained therefrom. The same machine could be used in both institutions.

I have obtained information on this subject and the most practical model would be the Thermo 21 C. at $172.50. There is also a smaller model at $159.50.

If you take into consideration the strenuous work entailed by hand washing, you will readily understand why I recommend this expenditure, insofar as the same machine could be used for the school and the hospital.

Yours truly,

Dear Sirs:

Last Fall, Doctor Lavallée, indian agent of Bersimis Reserve, according to what he told me, sent you a letter concerning rooms in Bersimis indian school cellar which were supposed to serve as recreation halls for the pupils. He said he explained to you how those rooms would need additional work so as to make them suitable for that purpose and for other purposes. According to his estimate, this additional work would require an expense of about three hundred dollars. I guess such expense should be sufficient to transform those rooms into a good recreation hall for the children, or into a good assembly hall which could shelter the Indians on rainy days, whenever the agent or some inspector would want to speak to them, or serve as an evening-hall for concerts and plays given once in a while by the scholars (indian just as well as canadian) drilled by their Nun-teachers or for instructive and interesting movies censured and given by myself and my assistant-priest, or some other purposes. Doctor Lavallée told me lately he never had any answer in that concerning.....

As a matter of fact, those rooms have been almost useless ever since that indian school was built; at least until last Fall, when, with the agent's agreement, we started giving movies with Canadian Government 16 mm. films and other interesting films rented from companies. Yet those rooms are not very suitable for that purpose; but there is no other place. The total net profit of those movies, though very modest, is for the benefit of our church, which church has been in debt for over ten thousand dollars ever since the depression began. Still if you should decide that you can't favor us with the sum of three hundred dollars for the desired work, I would still be most thankful to you if you would at least grant us the sum of two hundred dollars for that purpose. I would try and pay the balance with our movies profit, although it might take us a year's profit to pay such balance.

In the meantime, waiting for a prompt and favorable reply, either to Doctor Lavallée, your agent for Bersimis Reserve, or to myself, I remain,

Yours very truly,

Reverend Father Denis Doucet
"Head-Missionary"
Bersimis, P.Q.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of a letter from Rev. Denis Doucet, requesting an expenditure of $200 or $300 in making improvements to the Bersimis Day School. Our Appropriation this year has been reduced, and we are, therefore, informing Father Doucet that we will have no funds for this purpose.

When writing the Department, Father Doucet states that he has been using rooms in the basement of the school for concerts, and that moving pictures have been shown by using 16 mm. films.

As far as our files show, no permission has been given by the Department for holding movies, and the use of films, without due precaution being taken, constitutes a fire hazard. I regret that it is necessary to advise you that the holding of movies in the basement of this building must be discontinued, but the Department is obliged to protect its property.

Dear Sir,

Simultaneously with our annual requisition, I beg to submit the following. Our Convent has no attic but big cellars which are not of much use to us. They are always open and full of dust from the classrooms and from the heating plant. It is quite impossible to have a clean corner in which to store trunks, linen, etc. I believe it is not asking too much to request that a room be arranged in the cellar with large cupboards. This would not be very expensive and would be very useful to us.

Moreover, all things that are in use finally wear out. We have thus no spare bed sheets. Could you let us have enough money to buy 4 or 6 pairs of flannelette sheets?

With regard to the teaching of domestic science, would it be possible to obtain a little money this year? The cotton bought last year has been made into shirts for the boys and aprons and drawers for the girls. You have no idea how useful to the children these lessons have been. This is, after all, the most important part of the programme in this place.
Hoping to receive a favourable reply, I am,

Yours gratefully,

(sgd.) Sister Sainte Jeanne.
Monsieur le Secrétaire,

En même temps que notre réunion annuelle je me permets de faire une petite réclame. Vous savez comment notre Couvent est bâti, c'est-à-dire sans grenier et avec d'immenses caves qui ne nous donnent aucune commodité, étant toujours ouvertes elles sont le point de ralliement de toutes les poussières des classes, du bois et du charbon. Donc aucun moyen de concevoir un coin propre pour y mettre salaisons, linge etc... Je ne crois pas être trop exigeante en demandant de faire une chambre dans la cave, avec de grandes armoires, ce qui ne serait pas très dispendieux et nous serait d'une grande utilité.

Souscrire comme tout ce qui serait nécessaire à notre dernière change de draps de lit je vous prie d'avoir la bonne de nous fournir la somme nécessaire à l'achat de 4 ou 6 paires de draps de flanellette.

Et pour l'enseignement ménager ? Donnez-vous
une petite somme encore cette année? Le coton acheté l'an dernier a servi à la confection de chemises pour garçons, tabliers et calècons pour fillettes et nous ne savons encore combien ils profiteront des leçons qu'ils reçoivent, et c'est bien cette matière qui leur est plus utile ici.

Espérant être exaucée en mes petites requêtes,

Je me sousserai,

Votre obligée

Sœur Sainte Jeanne

Dear Sir:

Re Your letter of May 11, 3/1/5.

This hall is part of the ground floor of the school and covers a full 1/3 of the floor space of the whole building. It has a cement floor and the walls are the foundations themselves. There are windows, heating and lighting and W.Cs.

In order to make use of this hall, it should have a wood floor, a ceiling made up of light material, not necessarily wood, and the walls should be painted.

According to the original plan of the building, this hall was to be used for that purpose, but it never was finished. It could be used mainly as a recreation hall. In fact, the children are provided with no place for that purpose. In the summer time, when the weather is nice, they go out, but in the winter time and on rainy days, they are packed in the classrooms and that is where they spend their recreation time.

The hall could at the same time be used as a Committee hall where the Indians could hold their council meetings or their caucuses.

It would cost approximately $200. for material and from $50. to $75. for labour.

Yours truly,

N.-D. de Bethsiamits, April 7, 1937.

Mr. Secretary,

I would like to bring to your attention several points I believe would be worth considering. Our house, which was built in 1923, has not been repaired since then, and is in need of such repairs in many cases. The roof leaks and, in winter, the snow melts through in such fashion that since the middle of January, we have had to keep 6 or 8 containers on the window sills to catch the water which comes in through the windows. The outside walls are slowly crumbling away, and in many places where the bricks have fallen out, there is no longer any cement around the windows, all of which causes the house to be very cold. On some days, although the furnace gage varies from 150 to 160 degrees in our classrooms, the thermometer indicates only 60 degrees above zero.

Inside the house, the frost, each winter, has caused the plaster to fall in many cases, and I believe it would not be too much to ask that you renew the walls which have been blackened and yellowed by the winter leaking through the roof. There are also a few other necessary improvements which would require immediate attention. A few feet behind the Convent, they had to dig a drain before the building could be erected, and now, this drain is crumbling away each year and the solidity of the foundations will soon be imperilled. After snow melted, last year, there were large holes where the earth had fallen away and which we filled in with soft earth, but I do not think that should prove to be sufficient. In front of the entrance to the building, the sidewalk is practically all broken up, and a few of the boards we have laid across are all broken, and thus have become dangerous for the children. You must also understand that in a classroom of Indians, it would be very useful to spray some disinfectant at least a few times a week, especially in this case, seeing that for some time now the children have been suffering, in general,
from the scabies and the itch, and that there is no other possible means of stopping the progress of infection. Lastly, I would request that you authorize us to spend the sum of $10.00 to renew small housekeeping articles.

I trust you will take these requests into serious consideration, and I remain,

Yours faithfully,

(Signed) Sr. Ste-Jeanne,
Superior.

N.B.- The Agent being absent, I have been unable to have him sign my requisition.

Monsieur:

Re/ la votre du 27 Avril faisant suite à une réclamation de la Rvde Mère Supérieure, concernant les réparations à l'Ecole de Bersimis.

Sur mes derniers estimés j'ai demandé 300.00 pour peinturage des portes et fenêtres à l'extérieur et mastiquage des vitres; depuis 14 ans que la bâtisse existe, rien de tel n'a été fait. Pas nécessaire d'être savant pour savoir que c'est nécessaire.

Ce que dit la Rvde Mère sur sa lettre est malheureusement strictement vrai.

Le trottoir qui entoure l'Ecole est en ruine.

L'eau et la neige pénètrent autour des fenêtres et châssis et le vent toujours du côté ou il vente.

La bâtisse a été excessivement mal construite. La brique menace de tomber de partout. L'on peut, à la main, enlever les briques. Le mortier est en partie disparu de telle sorte qu'entre les briques il y a un espace. Malgré que la fournaise soit amplement suffisante pour chauffer la bâtisse, on réussit à dépenser trente tonnes de charbon par hiver. Les enfants y gelent à cœur d'hiver, du côté où vient le vent, cependant que du côté opposé au vent, les autres grillent.

Sur ma demande et avec moi, il y a deux ans, l'Inspecteur Fabien, a examiné en détail la bâtisse et a pris note de la situation. Je n'en ai plus jamais entendu parler. Il est entendu que d'ici peu d'années, les murs tomberont par pans, s'ils ne sont pas réparés.

La réparation générale de la bâtisse qui s'impose est de mettre du mortier entre chacune des briques; cela veut dire autant de travail que de faire un mur neuf. Tous les murs intérieurs sont délabrés et tombent en ruine, cela cause par l'eau qui a filtré de partout et un peu aussi parce qu'ils ont été mal faits. Alors pour réparer l'extérieur convenablement et refaire l'intérieur, je crois qu'une dépense d'environ $1500.00 seront nécessaires.

Le toit aussi devra être réparé; il est actuellement en bardeau; je suis d'avis qu'il vaudra mieux le recouvrir en toile; cela pourra représenter 4 à 500.00 au moins.

Avec le $250.00 alloué cette année, évidemment, aucun de ces travaux ne peut être entrepris. Ce que nous pouvons faire est de peindre les ouvertures, ce qui est urgent, autant de bloquer l'eau autour des fenêtres en posant du mortier autour des briques qui les entourent.
L'un ou l'autre de ces travaux coutera approximativement le même prix. Pour faire les deux qui sont aussi urgents l'un que l'autre, il en faudra le double. Vous en déciderez comme il vous plaira.

B.A.V.

Sir,

Re your letter of April 27th., with reference to a complaint made by the Reverend Mother Superior, in connection with the repairs to be made to the Bersimis school.

In my last estimates I have asked for $300.00 to paint the outside doors and windows and puttying the glass; nothing has been done for the last 14 years, and no one need to be a learned man to know that the thing is necessary.

Mother Superior states the exact truth in her letter.

The sidewalks around the school are crumbling into pieces.

Rain, snow and wind filter around the windows and sashes.

The building was not at all well built in the first place. The bricks are nearly falling off; one can take them out with the hand. The mortar is partly fallen off, leaving open spaces between the bricks. Though the furnace is sufficient to heat the building it takes 30 tons of coal every winter. The children are suffering from cold on the side exposed to the wind, while they are burning on the other side.

Two years ago, on my request, Inspector Fabien and
I examined the building in all its details and took note of its condition. I never heard about it since. It is understood that in a few years the walls will fall down if they are not repaired.

The general repairs required consist in fixing the bricks which is as much work as building a new wall. The inside walls need repairs because water filtering through and because they were not well built in the first place. Then a sum of about $1,500 would be required to conveniently repair the outside and inside walls.

The roof needs also to be repaired. Actually it is covered with shingles. In my opinion it would be better to cover it with sheet iron. That work would cost between $400 and $500.

With the $250 allowance that work could not be undertaken this year. The only thing that could be done would be to paint the doors and windows, which is urgently needed, or to attempt to stop the water from filtering around the windows.

Both works would involve approximately the same expenditure. Twice the amount would be required to do both jobs.

Yours truly,

(Signed) Dr. E. Lavallée,
Agent.
Ottawa, June 4, 1937.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 15th ultimo, with reference to certain repairs and improvements which you consider necessary at the Bersimis Indian Day School.

As you were informed in official letter of April 27th, last, the sum of $250.00 is available during the current fiscal year for repairs to the Bersimis School. It is noted, from your letter, that this amount would enable you to prevent the water from filtering around the windows, and this work should be done. If this work does not require the total amount of $250.00, the balance may be expended in making whatever repairs you consider most necessary. The point to be kept in mind is that the total amount of the repairs and improvements at the Bersimis School must not exceed $250.00.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Department des affaires indiennes

Messieurs,

Comme le terme de l'année scolaire s'approche et que chaque institution s'occupe de se procurer des prix et des récompenses, comme encouragement pour leurs élèves, je vous envoie aussi une énigme la moins en faveur de nos bons petits Indiens. Depuis quelques ans au moins, ces étudiants écoliers n'ont reçu comme prix de leur assiduité et de leur application que des bagatelles, que l'ingéniosité, des bricolages ont été offerts de parents et d'amis; le Department ne s'y était pas rendu cette année ces ressources nous manquent c'est pourquoi je voudrais vous demander de vouloir bien faire votre part aujourd'hui. $12.00 plus si vous le voulez, nous ferait grand plaisir à ceux qui auront démontré depuis nombre d'années au milieu de ces pauvres enfants sauvages et à ceux enfants dociles et appliqués.

April 5th, 1938.

Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Sirs:

As the end of the school-year approaches and every institution is trying to obtain prizes and articles as encouragement for their pupils, may I also ask that you give something in favour of our Indians. For the last four years at least, these studious Indians have received as prizes for their application nothing but trifles which their teachers were able to obtain from parents and friends, the Department having furnished nothing. This year we have been unable to obtain nothing and so I would like to request that the Department do its share now. We who have devoted ourselves for quite a number of years to these poor Indians would greatly appreciate receiving at least $12.00 to this end, or more if possible.

I trust you will give this your kind attention as you well understand that emulation and assiduity cannot be maintained without some form of reward. The Agent shares our view in the matter and judges the thing to be absolutely necessary this year.

I, Sister Marie du Carmel, Superior and teacher here at Bethsiamits for the last twenty years can assure you that we have never taken advantage of the Department's favours neither for ourselves nor for our pupils. That is why I am confident of obtaining the small allowance requested this year.

Thanking you in anticipation, I remain,

Yours truly,

(sgd) Sister Marie du Carmel,
Superior.
Dear Madam:

I have your letter of the 6th instant requesting a grant to purchase prizes to be given to the children at the end of June.

We have received similar requests from many other Indian Schools but owing to lack of funds it has been found impossible to favourably consider these requests. I, therefore, regret that the grant that you ask for for the Bersimis School cannot be allowed.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Sister Marie du Carmel,
Superior,
Bersimis Indian Day School,
Bersimis, Que.

Dear Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 22nd instant with regard to the request made by the teachers of Bersimis Indian Day School and to give you, in reply, the following information:

1.-Re: Material for domestic science classes.
The Principal of the School requests that she be authorized to procure the necessary material for an amount of $10.00 approximately and then produce the invoice.

2.-Re: Purchase of brooms, mops, dusters and repairing two alarm clocks.
The Reverend Sister wanted 5 brooms, 3 mops, 2 dusters and two clocks repaired. As the matter was urgent, I supplied the school with five brooms, 3 mops and ordered two dusters to be delivered a little later. As to the alarm clocks I was informed that the repairing might cost more than the purchase of new ones.

All these articles including $10.00 for material for domestic science would amount to $22.00 approximately.

I beg to recommend that the Reverend Sister's request be granted.

Your obedient servant,

Mr R.A. Hoey,

Ottawa, Ont., Sept. 13, 1938.

Sir:

I beg to submit the following Inspection Report made from August 4th and following days, in Jersim's, Quebec.

School House

The mortar between the bricks has been partly replaced, or rather refilled with cement, but there remains to be finished the front entrance and the side walls, as well as the north-east end of the building, and the longer these repairs are delayed the more defective will the building be. It is difficult to believe that after only fourteen years such repairs should be necessary to this building; it is what I call a poor job, whoever made it.

The sidewalk about the school and hospital is all rotted and considered dangerous. It was built fourteen years ago and poor judgment used in its construction. It is four feet wide, eight 6" wide 2" planks laid lengthwise and close together. I suggest rebuilding it with six 6" wide 2" planks lengthwise with 1" space between, which will prevent moisture and be plenty wide. It is 500' long and 5" x 5 cross pieces under at three-foot intervals.

Inside: The plaster ceiling is falling off; I would recommend metal ceiling to replace plaster.

Light repairs are needed to some of the walls in the following rooms; entrance hall, cloak room and Junior Indian classroom. All walls need whitewashing and all woodwork should be painted as soon as possible.

The furnace in the cellar is in very good condition and the place is kept very clean.

Electricity is produced by a Canadian Fairbanks Morse Generator, 32 volts, connected to a 3 H.P. Canadian Fairbanks Morse gasoline engine and glass storage batteries. The batteries having been renewed in 1931, they are now practically obsolete. The system installed in 1924 is not giving satisfactory service for school and hospital. May I suggest, therefore, that this engine and generator with a new set of storage batteries be installed in the agent's residence at Seven Islands, where there is no electricity and such installation having been under consideration in the past.

There is also connected to this engine a water pump which is in very good condition, and giving
satisfactory service. This could remain here, but I would suggest the installation of a water pump at Seven Islands whenever this suggested change is made here.

I recommend a more powerful installation to replace the actual one; 110 volts, 5 H.P. engine and generator, which should be sufficient to improve the lighting here, in the hospital, at the Agent's residence and the R.C.M.P. quarters.

I hope sufficient funds are available to take care of this change in the very near future.

J. Thibault.
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Quebec.
Ottawa,
November 4, 1938.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 4th instant with reference to repairs and improvements required at the Bersimis Indian day school.

No provision was made in the current year's appropriation for the very large expenditure that you request.

Paint for the blackboards will be sent to the teacher but it should not be necessary to employ a man for two days to paint the blackboards. This is a very simple operation and anyone can put paint on the blackboards in a very short time. If the cupboard in the kitchen is really necessary you may expend an amount not exceeding $11.00 for material and labour.

The Department is prepared to consider reshingling the building but it is considered that your estimate is altogether too high.

I note that you mention that 45,000 shingles will be required and that these can be secured at $4.00 a thousand. Please let me know if these are first quality shingles and the name and address of the firm from whom you secured the quotation.

You mention that 100 gallons of shingle paint is required. How many coats of shingle stain did you intend to give these shingles? The Department estimates that only 30 gallons is required for one coat.

You state that it will require 2 men for 60 days to do the necessary work. I understand that a competent tradesman can lay 200 square feet of shingles a

W. Barolet, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Bersimis, Que.
day; consequently the 45,000 shingles should be laid by the 2 men in a period not longer than 12 days. This would reduce the charge for labour to $62.40 instead of your estimate of $312.00. Please let me know if you can get the work done in the period of time mentioned and also state whether it is your intention to employ Indians or white men. If white men are to be employed you should let me know the name and address of the person who you consider could do the work.

The replacing of the mortar or cement between the bricks appears to be necessary but your estimate seems extremely high. You mention that the following material will be required: cement - $12.00, lime - $7.50, bricks - $2.50, or a total expenditure for material of $22.00. To do the necessary labour, however, you estimate the cost at $520.00. It seems out of the question that the labour would cost such a very large amount in view of the very small amount of material that is being used. Please give this matter further attention and ascertain if the work could not be done at a much more reasonable figure.

The estimates for the other work which you suggest also appear very high and as no funds are available no consideration can be given to them at the present time.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 16th instant with reference to repairs to the Bersimis Indian day school and beg to give you, in reply, the following explanations regarding reshingling of the building, shingle stain, replacing of mortar or cement between the bricks:

I made my estimates according to information which I got from traders of Bersimis and I regret sincerely that quantities and prices do not correspond with your figures; I shall be pleased to get more precise information from tradesmen and traders outside of Bersimis.

My intention was to employ a white man for the main work and an Indian as a helper. I allowed for labour more time than I really expected it would take in case of being compelled to employ tradesmen from outside of Bersimis in which case the salary for each man would be no less than $7.00 per day, that is $5.00 per day for labour, plus $2.00 for board, besides the expense for transportation.

I cannot say exactly how long two men would take to lay the shingles but I am sure that the work cannot be done in 12 days by men of this locality, that is including the removal of old shingles and the necessary construction of a scaffolding and its changing of places seven times at least.

As to shingle stain, my intention was to have shingles to stand in the stain, the shingles thus saturated with the stain ought to last longer but, of course, this operation requires much more stuff. I shall inform you of the price for first quality shingles as soon as I get quotation from outside trader.

Mr. R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.
As for the replacing of mortar or cement between the bricks, I made my estimate from what had already been paid for the same kind of work. In 1937, $223.00 were paid for labour for about one third of the work which remains to be done; at that rate the labour would cost $446.00 for the projected work and I added some seventy five dollars for the scaffolding which has to be made to a large extent.

It is very hard to get accurate estimates for work of this kind as there is no real tradesman at Bersimis. I possibly could get Georges Deschenes, a tradesman from the neighborhood, to make estimates for such repairs; I beg to suggest that I be authorized to expend the sum of $15.00 for that purpose.

Your obedient servant,

Wilfrid Barelet

(Wilfrid Barelet, M.D.)
Indian Agent.

MEMORANDUM:

MR. R. A. HOEY

In company with Doctor McGill, I visited Bersimis on Monday, June 26th. In accordance with your telegram of June 15th, I asked Doctor Barolet to allow me to read the correspondence dealing with repairs required for the Bersimis School. Doctor Barolet's filing system does not appear to be very efficient, as he was unable to find his or our letters. As I had some idea of what was required, I visited the School.

It appears that the building was erected in or about 1925 by a Hull firm. The Doctor says that the roof leaked the first year after it was built, so you will have some idea of the workmanship. Cedar shingles usually last more than twelve years.

The plaster inside is badly cracked, perhaps from frost heaving. In many places, especially the kitchen of the teacher's residence, the ceiling has been temporarily repaired with cloth. From observation, I would say that the ceilings of the rooms should be replastered or possibly they could be tinned the same as the class-rooms.

The ceiling near the walls shows water stains on one side and I would recommend that a patching job to the roof would be sufficient to meet requirements and could be carried out for a small fraction of the estimated cost of new roof. I would think that maybe $75.00 would be sufficient.

The sidewalk (plank) is in very poor condition. This walk is used by the Indians all the time and I think that it

...........might be
might be taken up altogether and replaced by cinders, crushed stone or gravel. The first cost of which would be much less than a plank walk and the subsequent upkeep would be nil. If the plank walk were replaced by another plank walk, it would soon need repairs, as the spruce plank which appears to be used on the North Shore soon rots when placed close to the ground.

The Sisters complained of the grease trap in the kitchen; this is a barrel-like affair through which the water from the sink passes before going into the sewer. It was installed with the idea of obtaining grease to make soft soap. It has proved unsatisfactory and in warm weather is the source of a very bad odour. This trap might be removed and the sink waste-pipe attached directly to the pipe leading to the sewer. The cost of this change should be very small unless a plumber has to be brought in from Rinskowski or some outside point with consequent heavy transportation charges.

Gibson Armstrong,
Head Clerk,
Welfare & Training Division.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of a report from Mr. Armstrong regarding his inspection of the Bersimis Indian Day School.

Mr. Armstrong recommends that the roof be patched, and he considers that this work could be done at a cost not exceeding $75.00. You may therefore make immediate arrangements for the patching of the roof on the distinct understanding, that the total cost of material and labour will not exceed $75.00.

It is reported that the plank side-walk is in very poor condition. What remains of this walk should be taken up and replaced by cinders, crushed stone, or gravel. Please let me know what it would cost to secure one of the three materials mentioned.

The grease trap in the kitchen is proving unsatisfactory. This trap should be removed and the sink waste-pipe attached directly to the pipe leading to the sewer. The cost of this change should be very small.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. Welfare & Training.

Bersimis, Que. August 30th, 1939.

Dear Sir,

With reference to your letter of July 8th, regarding repairs to be made to the roof of the school building, the sidewalk and the grease trap in the kitchen of the school, I beg to report as follows:

1- Mr. Eugene Miller, a tradesman, has examined the roof and said that it is not worth repairing; he himself would not take the job knowing that he could not make a satisfactory work. Mr. Miller suggests that the whole roof be renewed.

2- About the sidewalk Mr. Miller says that it is hard even approximately to estimate the cost of removing and replacing it by cinders, crushed stone or gravel. He appears to be rather in favour of replacing it by gravel and making 5 feet wide in order to have a better chance to round it. The cost would not be less than $125.00.

3- The grease trap has been removed and I am awaiting for a special pipe to make a connection with the sink waste-pipe and the pipe leading to the sewer.

Your obedient servant,

(Wilfrid Barelet)

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 30th ultimo with reference to repairs at the Bersimis Indian day school.

In your letter of May 4 you estimated that it would cost approximately $770.00 to place a new roof on the Bersimis school. There are no funds available for such a heavy expenditure. I, therefore, consider that you should proceed with minor repairs to make the building habitable during the winter. It is understood, of course, that in making these repairs the expenditure must not exceed $75.00.

In view of the amount required for a new sidewalk the Department finds it impossible to provide the funds that would be necessary and consequently no action can be taken at the present time.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

November 18, 1939.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of your requisition dated the 7th instant for a large number of electric light bulbs for the school, hospital and Agency residence at Bersimis. Please let me know why you apparently require such a large number of bulbs. The quantities mentioned on your requisition appear excessive. You should also state why you require bulbs of different sizes. It is doubtful if the capacity of the electric light plant that is installed will satisfactorily use some of the bulbs that you request.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hosey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. W. Barolet,
Indian Agent,
Bersimis, Que.
Dear Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 18th instant with regard to my requisition for electric light bulbs and to furnish you, in reply, with the following explanation:

At the school building there are 43 lights with bulbs of different sizes and as a bulb, at times, is liable to become useless within a few months, 20 spare bulbs for such a building do not appear to me to be excessive. Actually, there are bulbs missing in some rooms because they have been taken away to some other rooms where light was urgently needed. One cannot expect to have the bulbs interchanged from one room to another in proportion of the light needed. After replacing missing or burnt bulbs there will be but a few spare bulbs left.

At the agency house there are 28 lights and the same explanation stands for this building.

As to the hospital building there are but 10 lights and the number of bulbs requisitioned might be reduced to 20.

I have to state that all the sizes asked for are actually used satisfactorily larger sizes being used where better light is needed. Of course, the capacity of the electric light plant would not suffice were all the lights used at the same time which case never occurs.

Hoping that these explanations will be found satisfactory I remain,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

Mr. R.A. Heey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa,
December 2, 1939.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 23rd ultimo regarding electric light bulbs for the school, hospital and agency residence at Bersimis you may purchase 21 electric light bulbs for the use of the school, 15 for the use of the hospital and 15 for the Agency residence. It is noted from the requisition that you were purchasing bulbs of 32 voltage. The Department understands that the plant at Bersimis is 110 volts. In purchasing the electric light bulbs authorized in this letter you should be careful to purchase exactly what is required.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dr. W. Barolet,
Indian Agent,
Bersimis, Que.

Monsieur le Secrétaire des Affaires Indiennes,
Ottawa,

Monsieur le Secrétaire,

J'ai bien reçu votre lettre circulaire nous demandant d'économiser le plus possible. En réalité, cette ordonnance ne nous concerne pas directement, car nous demandons à votre Établissement, depuis 3 ans, à ma connaissance, ont été très restrictives. Sans oublier votre recommandation, j'ose toutefois me adresser votre requête pour la nouvelle année scolaire espérant que vous ne refuserez pas de les remplir. M. l'Agent en a pris connaissance et il n'y a rien retenu. Il m'autorise à me le adresser moi-même.

Notre ancien, qui est à notre service depuis 17 ans, dit que les articles réclamés pour la fourniture et l'entretien de la maison n'ont pas encore été remplacés, à sa connaissance. Ce qui prouve qu'ils sont indispensables.

Comme nous devons aller en vacances pour quelque temps, pourriez-vous nous faire parvenir ces effets par le bateau? Une gruelette de transport vers la mi-juin afin que nous puissions les mettre en sûreté.
Je dois vous dire que j'ai dû dépenser, pendant les 2 dernières années, près de $15., sur l'argent de votre Communauté, pour des objets et des réparations d'urgence. Il le fallait bien jusqu'à ce qu'il n'y ait moyen d'obtenir même quelques sous, ici; c'est presque la misère. Votre mission s'en va à l'abandon et les plafonds, dans nos appartements, menacent de nous tomber sur la tête. Notre Mère Générale ne conseille de nous faire connaître cet état de choses, ce qui ne s'est pas encore vu; elle ajoute que le Département l'ignore, car il avait l'habitude de donner ce que réclamaient les Institutions. Est-ce que vous ne pouviez pas nous autoriser à acheter notre nourriture au marché nécessaire et l'indispensable chez un de nos marchands ici qui présenterait ensuite le compte à M. votre Agent?

Un autre point, par le passé, les remèdes nous étaient fournis gratuitement. Maintenant il nous faut acheter, avec notre argent, ceux qui nous sont nécessaires. Est-ce que les obligations ne sont plus les mêmes? Vous nous rendez grandement service, si vous voulez bien répondre à cette question.

Espérant que vous laignerez prendre en bonne considération les demandes que je vous adresse présentement, je demeure,

Votre très humble,

S.M. de St. Octave, s.B.C.,
Supr. Directrice des Classes Indiennes.
Indian School, Betsiamitsi,
May 6, 1940.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Sir:

I have received your circular letter requesting us to economize as much as possible. I do not think that these instructions apply to us particularly, as for the last three years our requests to the Department have been very reasonable.

Without overlooking your recommendation however, I am sending you our requisition for the new school-year, in the hope that you will not refuse to send us the items needed. The Agent has gone over this requisition and did not strike out anything, and he authorized me to send it to you direct.

Our caretaker, who has been with us for 15 years, claims that as far as he is aware the articles requested for the furnace and for the upkeep of the house have never been renewed, which proves that they are absolutely needed.

As we are to leave on a few weeks holiday, could you send us these items by the freight boat "Sept-Iles" around the middle of June in order that they may be stored away in a safe place. I must say that in the last two years I was compelled to spend almost $75.00 out of the funds of the community for urgent repairs and needed articles. We had to do so as it is impossible for us to secure even a few cents here. Your house is falling to pieces and the ceiling in our apartments threatens to fall on top of us. Our General Superior has urged me to bring this situation to your attention. She commands that the Department must not be aware of the seriousness of the situation, as it has always in the past given what was required by the school-teachers. Could you not authorize us to purchase at least what is essential from local merchants who could then send the bill to your Agent?
Further, I wish to point out that in the past the medicine was supplied to us free of charge. Now, we must purchase with our own money what is needed. Has there been a change of policy in this respect? We should be obliged if you would reply to these questions.

I trust that you will consider favourably the present request and I remain,

Your humble servant,

(Sgd.) S. M. de St-Octave,
Superior and Director
of Indian classes.
Ottawa:
June 3, 1940.

Dear Sir:

In a letter dated May 6 the Sister Superior of the Bersimis School wrote to the Department regarding repairs and furnishings which she stated were necessary. In view of the decision not to operate this school during the academic year 1940-41 the Department considers it unnecessary to supply the articles requested by the Principal.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dr. W. Barolet,
Indian Agent,
Bersimis, Que.

Extract from Inspector Thibault's report on the Bersimis Agency dated October 31, 1941.

The school was closed except for one classroom which is being used for white children.

I am just making a mention of it, as I do not expect that much funds are available at this time, besides it would be too late in the season to make any repairs this year.

As you will see on the annexed photograph, the sidewalks which I had recommended to be rebuilt in 1939 are a menace, and I took it upon myself to order the removal of the whole thing to avoid any possible accident, as I feel it will be much safer to walk on the ground than on such a dilapidated sidewalk.
Ottawa, October 31, 1941.

Dr. H.W. McGill,

I beg to submit a report of a special inspection made October 10-17th at Bersimis Agency, with reference to a memorandum of October 2, 1941.

SCHOOL HOUSE

The school was closed except for one classroom which is being used for white children.

Some part of the outside walls, which have not been repaired, as previously recommended, are dilapidating more and more, as the mortar between the bricks is falling out. I am just making a mention of it, as I do not expect that much funds are available at this time, besides it would be too late in the season to make any repairs this year.

As you will see on the annexed photograph, the sidewalks which I had recommended to be rebuilt in 1939 are a menace, and I took it upon myself to order the removal of the whole thing to avoid any possible accident, as I feel it will be much safer to walk on the ground than on such a dilapidated sidewalk.

The Agent had quite a time deciding the sisters to go away after the school term, as at least one or two of them insisted on occupying the building, as they used to do in years previous to the change to a short term course; however when they were told that the Department would not heat the building during the winter, they decided to go. I believe it was a good economy to cut down the school term to four months. If the Sisters are not interested in short school term, they could be replaced by lay teachers. I have learned confidentially of certain things that happened at the school, which I do not care to mention in details, and it might be advisable to have a change in one or two of the past staff.

Jude Thibault,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Quebec Inspectorate.
Ottawa, October 31, 1941.

Dr. H.W. McGill

I beg to submit a report of a special inspection made October 10-17th at Bersimis Agency, with reference to a memorandum of October 2, 1941.

GARDENING:

The Sisters have shown very little interest in domestic teaching and none at all in gardening. The teaching of gardening to boys and girls should receive a certain consideration. In 1939, I suggested that a certain piece of land, next to the Agency lot belonging to Indian Councillor, Malek Collard be used. This land was offered free of charge by Mr. Collard for a school garden. The Agent's wife has made a success of her own garden, and she has offered to take charge of such gardening course for the benefit of the Indian children, and without remuneration.

There are a few Indian gardens, more or less properly cultivated, and the young Indians should gain by learning better ways of cultivating a garden, which would before many years provide the Indian families with lot more vegetable food than they are getting at present. This Agency will never be a farming reserve, but there is no excuse for not having many more gardens.

When looking over the boundary line of the two square miles of Indian fuel wood, accompanied by Mr. O'Hurley and Agent, they drew my attention on a price of land of about 8 or 10 acres in superficie which would only require a little drainage to make one of the nicest garden on the north shore; a couple of good ditches is all that it requires to drain it properly and in my opinion the cost would not exceed much over one or two hundred dollars, and could be made by hand by the Indians.

Returning to the matter of school garden, next to the Agency lot, it would be eighty feet long and one hundred and ten feet long; part of the Agency fence would be moved for one end and there would be about two hundred feet of fence to build. The materials required to build the fence or rather, part of it, would be:

- 20 round posts 6" x 7' procurable on the Reserve
- 30 pieces-spruce 2" x 4" x 12'
- 300 slats - do 3" x 7/8" x 4'

With nails, labor and paint, it should not cost much over $50.00 however we could get prices during the winter for the studdings and slats, which would have to come from the outside, for delivery in the Spring of 1942. I recommend that the ploughing to be done this Fall if at all possible, as it is very important to do so if we intend to follow the suggestion of a school garden.

Jude Thibault,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Quebec Inspectorate.

Dear Sir,

In regard to the school garden next to the Agency lot as suggested in your letter of April 23rd, I beg to inform you that the fence around the garden is now built. The expenditure for materials and labour amounted to $34.97 as shown in vouchers Nos. 857-858-859-860 and 861.

The painting remains to be done. The fence being the continuation of that of the agency house I beg to request that I be permitted to have the entire length, 500 ft., painted; two coats on the new fence and one coat on the old one. The work would require 3 gallons of white paint, one gallon of black paint and one gallon of boiled linseed oil.

The local traders being out of this material actually, I beg to suggest that you place an order for same with the Crown Diamond Paint Co. Ltd., of Montreal, Que., I note that their prices are much lower than those of Bersimis dealers.

I estimate that one man can do the painting of the whole fence in 4 days @ $2.00 per day which would make the total expenditure for the building of the fence to about $55.00, including lumber, nails, labour and painting. This work can be done by Indian labour.

Your obedient servant,

(Wilfrid Barolet)

Ottawa,
February 9, 1943.

Memorandum for file:

Rt. Rev. Napoleon Labrie, Vicar Apostolic of the Gulf of St. Laurence, interviewed Mr. Hoey and myself this morning with reference to the Bersimis Indian Day School. The Bishop pointed out that a number of the Indian families at Bersimis do not go trapping in the winter and, as a result, there are 30 or 40 children of school age who are not receiving any training. Consequently he strongly urged that arrangements be made to re-open the Bersimis School for the full academic period each year.

Mr. Hoey pointed out to the Bishop the reasons for only operating a summer school. One of the very heavy expenditures was the purchase of coal.

After discussing the matter fully it was decided to have Mr. Dube, a contractor of Rimouski, make an estimate of the cost of insulating the present Bersimis School in order to conserve the heat and explore the possibility of cutting off part of the building for winter use. This would naturally involve less heating. The Bishop expects that Mr. Dube will be at Bersimis in either April or May and Mr. Hoey promised the Bishop that at that time Inspector Thibault would also go to Bersimis and be with Mr. Dube when he is preparing his estimate of what could be done to make the building habitable for the winter.

The Bishop also suggested that the Indians should be made responsible for supplying the wood required for heating the building and Mr. Thibault will be instructed to interview them with regard to this matter.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Dear Bishop Labrie:

With reference to our interview on February 9, in connection with the Bersimis Indian Day School, I should appreciate your advising if you have any definite information regarding the date on which Mr. Dube the contractor will visit Bersimis. As it was agreed at the time of your visit, I hope to be able to have Inspector Thibault visit Bersimis when Mr. Dube is there.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Rt. Rev. Napoleon Labrie, C.J.M., D.D.,
Vicar Apostolic of Gulf of St. Lawrence,
Baie Comeau, Que.
Bersimis, Que. April 6, 1943

Mr. T.R.L. MacInnes, Secretary, Ottawa.

May I inquire if it is the intention of the Department to open the Bersimis Indian School this year the same as in 1942, that is to say from May 15 to September 15. If so, I beg to request that I be authorized to write to the Sisters of Notre-Dame du Bon Conseil, Chicoutimi, Que., and advise them to arrange to have two teachers to take charge of the School for that period at the same salary of last year, i.e. $60.00 a teaching month for the senior teacher and $50.00 a month for the junior teacher.

In case of the seasonal school being operated, I beg to request that I be authorized to make the following expenses for that purpose:

- 5 Cords of firewood for the kitchen stove, including the cutting and the storing: $37.00
- 25 Electric light bulbs, 32 volts @ 0.35 app.: $9.00
- Monthly cleaning of school-classes: $15.00
- Material for Domestic Science Class: $10.00
- Laundry Soap: $2.00
- Brooms and Sundries for cleaning purposes: $4.00

There are other school supplies that the teachers will most likely requisition on their arrival.

As to the necessity to heat the building in May and, possibly, in September, there is sufficient coal left in the bin for that purpose.

It is noted that you ask authority to purchase 25 electric light bulbs. In 1942 and in 1941 you asked the same authority when this school was being re-opened. As the school is only in operation for a three-month period in each year, the Department cannot see any reason for the necessity of supplying new electric light bulbs every year. I realize that the expenditure for these bulbs is not heavy, but at the same time, if they have to be replaced each year, it certainly appears that there must be carelessness on the part of someone. I will await your reply before making a decision on supplying additional bulbs this year.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Bersimis, Que. April 21, 1943

Mr. R.A. Hoey, Supt. of Welfare & Training, Ottawa.

With reference to your letter of the 19th instant, regarding the authority to purchase 25 electric light bulbs for the use of the seasonal school at Bersimis which keeps open for four months, I beg to report that there are still left at the school 10 electric bulbs in good order, 4 bulbs of 50 watts and 6 of 25 watts.

Of course, Paul Rock, our Caretaker, goes to the school building every day all the year long to look after the lighting plant and he goes specially at night during winter to run the motor in order to keep the battery-room warm and avoid the freezing of the batteries. So he is using electric light every day during the whole winter.

Fifteen bulbs, however, might be sufficient and I beg to request that I be authorized to purchase same.

Wilfred Barolet,
Indian Agent.

Bersimis, Que. May 29, 1943

RE: Proposed repairs to Bersimis Indian Day School

I beg to report upon my visit to the school today accompanied by our Agent, Dr. Barolet, and Mr. George Dube's contractor from Rimouski, Que.

Here are the different repairs suggested, which should remedy the heating situation in this twenty-year-old school.

**ROOF:**
- Remove all old shingles - Replace any rotted board
- Lay then an asphalt paper, of one ply, and over that, some heavy asphalt shingles.

**Outside walls:**
- Replace bad bricks between two and three hundred
- Fill joints between bricks with good cement mortar at the two ends as well as the three walls on main entrance side.
- Spray one coat of liquid waterproof compound (AQUA-PROOF) over all brick and cement work.

**WINDOWS:**
- Fill around each door and window frame with plastic cement.
- Replace broken glasses and putty where required.
- Paint with three coats of white lead paint all outside doors windows and woodwork.

**MAIN ENTRANCE:**
- Repair porch and steps - Build a permanent storm porch, with glass front.

**CEILING:**
- To be covered with "SPAGNOS" a perfect natural isolator four inches thick.

Mr. Dube is of the opinion that the above repairs should improve greatly our heating problem.

Mr. Dube will submit to you shortly his estimates on the above mentioned repairs and if the cost of such improvements are considered reasonable, I feel that we could give consideration to keep school opened as it used to be, at least for one year, remembering that Indian children are now more numerous, on account of many heads of families finding profitable employment, cutting wood on the limits or in the neighborhood, with a few better ones employed at Baie Comeau.

I expect to leave for Seven Islands by June first and intend to return here for a couple of days before going to Restigouche, as I would like to hold a meeting of the Band, which could not be held now due to many Indians being delayed on their way home, some of the rivers being free of ice since only a week or so.

Inspector of Indian Agencies

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Bersimis Indian Day School,
Bersimis Indian Agency, Electoral
District of Charlevoix-Saguenay.

The Bersimis School was erected in the fiscal year 1923-24 at an approximate cost of $52,000.00. Because of the cost of heating it, we discontinued classes during the winter of 1940 and since that time we have only operated a seasonal school during three or four months in the summer.

His Lordship Rt. Rev. Napoleon Labrie, Vicar Apostolic of the Gulf of St. Lawrence, interviewed me on February 9 last and strongly urged that the building be repaired and he suggested that we engage the services of Mr. J. Georges Dube, Rimouski, Que., as the Bishop was using this man's services to repair the church at Bersimis.

Inspector Thibault visited the Bersimis Reserve on May 29 and submitted a report recommending extensive repairs to the roof, outside walls and windows. The contractor mentioned above, Mr. Dube, also visited the school and on June 3 submitted a quotation of $3,412.00 to do the work that he considered was required.

About three weeks ago, previous to Mr. Doucet's departure for the Restigouche Reserve, I interviewed Mr. Jackson, who approved of Mr. Doucet's visiting Bersimis.
and inspecting the building. In a report dated August 2 Mr. Doucet stated that he had visited the reserve and, in his opinion, the school is greatly in need of repairs and, if these are not carried out at once, Mr. Doucet is of the opinion that the building will go to ruin. He stated that the foundation is good and recommended:

1. A new roof
2. Insulating ceilings
3. Caulking openings

Mr. Doucet considered that on the basis of the previous quotation of Mr. Dube the latter should be able to do the work just mentioned for $1,207.00. Mr. Dube was written to on August 7 and asked if he would do the work for the amount just stated. In a letter dated August 11, which has just been received, Mr. Dube offers to do the work for $1,450.00, giving as a reason for asking more than estimated by Mr. Doucet that labour is scarce and the transport of men and material to Bersimis expensive.

In view of the reports that we have received, both from Inspector Thibault and Mr. Doucet, I feel that if this building is to be maintained at all it is necessary for immediate repairs to be made. As mentioned in the first part of this memorandum, Bishop Labrie strongly recommends Mr. Dube as a competent contractor. Taking everything into consideration I recommend that Mr. Dube's price of $1,450.00 for repairing the building be accepted and I should appreciate having your approval for this expenditure.

Acting Director.
Ottawa,
August 13, 1943.

The Bersimis School was erected in the fiscal
year 1923-24 at an approximate cost of $32,000.00.
Because of the cost of heating it, we discontinued
classes during the winter of 1940 and since that time
we have only operated a seasonal school during three
or four months in the summer.

His Lordship Rt. Rev. Napoleon Labrie,
Vicar Apostolic of the Gulf of St. Lawrence, interviewed
me on February 9 last and strongly urged that the building
be repaired and he suggested that we engage the services
of Mr. J. Georges Dube, Rimouski, Que., as the Bishop
was using this man's services to repair the church at
Bersimis.

Inspector Thibault visited the Bersimis Reserve
on May 29 and submitted a report recommending extensive
repairs to the roof, outside walls and windows. The
contractor mentioned above, Mr. Dube, also visited the
school and on June 3 submitted a quotation of $5,412.00
to do the work that he considered was required.

About three weeks ago, previous to Mr. Doucet's
departure for the Restigouche Reserve, I interviewed Mr.
Jackson, who approved of Mr. Doucet's visiting Bersimis.
and inspecting the building. In a report dated August 2 Mr. Doucet stated that he had visited the reserve and, in his opinion, the school is greatly in need of repairs and, if these are not carried out at once, Mr. Doucet is of the opinion that the building will go to ruin. He stated that the foundation is good and recommended:

1. A new roof
2. Insulating ceilings
3. Caulking openings

Mr. Doucet considered that on the basis of the previous quotation of Mr. Dube the latter should be able to do the work just mentioned for $1,207.00. Mr. Dube was written to on August 7 and asked if he would do the work for the amount just stated. In a letter dated August 11, which has just been received, Mr. Dube offers to do the work for $1,450.00, giving as a reason for asking more than estimated by Mr. Doucet that labour is scarce and the transport of men and material to Bersimis expensive.

In view of the reports that we have received, both from Inspector Thibault and Mr. Doucet, I feel that if this building is to be maintained at all it is necessary for immediate repairs to be made. As mentioned in the first part of this memorandum, Bishop Labrie strongly recommends Mr. Dube as a competent contractor. Taking everything into consideration I recommend that Mr. Dube's price of $1,450.00 for repairing the building be accepted and I should appreciate having your approval for this expenditure.

Acting Director.

A few days ago, Mr. Roy, our present agent, communicated to me the contents of your letter with respect to the space in the convent which served the purpose of a parochial hall, under certain circumstances.

I am deeply grieved at this decision which deprives us of a hall so useful on certain occasions, and which helped us obtain a little revenue for our Church while serving recreational purposes for our Indians.

This hall was converted during the time Father Doucet was there, and at the sole expense of the Fabric, to be used as a recreational hall for the pupils of the Convent during the bad season. It also served, though rarely, for amateur theatricals. When the inspectors of the Department visited us, they were pleased to have such a hall for the meetings of Indians. The floor, the stage, the electrical lighting and chairs were supplied and paid by the Fabric. For my part, I certainly did not abuse the privilege of using this hall, because since my arrival at Bersimis we have had only one performance prepared and presented by our Indians and Canadians. The danger of fire is almost nil because the lighting is with electricity and, moreover, we do not allow smoking in this hall. When we had meetings, I stayed there myself to inspect the hall after each reunion.

When your letter arrived, we were organizing an amateur play for the month of June. We were all anxious for the success of this performance, probably the only one of the year. Useless to mention our deception and our regret. It seems to me that you could allow us to hold that performance since the arrangements are quite advanced. I have no doubt that you will kindly grant my request.

I therefore await your consoling reply by return mail. Dear Mr. Director, it has always been far from my mind to abuse of your kindness on my behalf; on the contrary, my motto has always been to work with you and the Department for the greater welfare of our Indians. I am devoting myself body and soul to our Indians; to make good citizens of them so that they will later be a pride to the Department.

I had the great pleasure of meeting you when I was a missionary along the Gulf of St. Lawrence. Your courtesy and kindness to me on this occasion remain as a precious memory. We understood and liked each other. I would be very glad to meet you again so that we might talk of mutual problems. Let us hope that this may happen soon.

I remain, Mr. Director,

Your devoted servant,

(Sgd) Luc Sirois, C.J.M.
Dear Father Sirois:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 11th instant, with reference to the building built by this Department and used for Indian school purposes on the Bersimis Reserve.

When the building was originally erected the auditorium, or hall, could be entered from the main portion of the school and in addition there was a door on the opposite side of the room which led outside.

My information is that without any authority from the Department someone arranged to close the door leading from the school to the auditorium and as a result there is only one narrow door leading from this room to the outside.

Departmental officials who have inspected this building definitely feel that in its present condition there is a serious fire hazard should a fire occur when the auditorium is occupied. No doubt you have read of the appalling loss of life at other places where fires have occurred recently and it was for this reason that the Department felt that until more suitable arrangements could be made to provide proper egress from this auditorium it was in the best interests of all parties concerned to discontinue its use for public gatherings.

It is my hope that a Departmental official will have an opportunity of visiting Bersimis in the near future and at that time I will make arrangements to have him interview you.

Yours truly,

Rev. L. Sirois, C.J.M.,
Bersimis, Que.

Cher Monsieur le Directeur,

Ces jours derniers, Monsieur Roy, notre Agent actuel, m'a donné communication de votre lettre au sujet du Local dans le Couvent qui servait en certaines circonstances de salle paroissiale.

Je suis profondément attristé de cette décision qui nous prive d'un local pourtant si utile à l'occasion et qui nous aidait à réaliser quelques revenus pour notre église tout en distrayant nos indiens.

Ce local a été aménagé au temps du Père Doucet et aux seuls frais de la Fabrique pour en faire une salle commune à l'usage des élèves du Couvent durant la mauvaise saison. Elle servait aussi quelque rarement pour de petites soirées. Lorsque Messieurs les Inspecteurs du Département venaient, ils étaient heureux d'avoir un local organisé pour réunir nos indiens. Les planchers, théâtre, l'éclairage électrique et les chaises ont été fournis et payés par la Fabrique. Pour ma part, je n'ai certes pas abusé de cette salle; car depuis mon séjour à Bersimis, nous n'avons fait qu'une séance préparée et donnée par nos indiens et canadiens. Le danger de feu n'existe à peu près pas; car l'éclairage est électrique, de plus nous ne permettons pas de fumer dans cette salle.
