Cher Monsieur le Directeur,

Ces jours derniers, Monsieur Roy, notre Agent actuel, m'a donné communication de votre lettre au sujet du Local dans le Couvent qui servait en certaines circonstances de salle paroissiale.

Je suis profondément attristé de cette décision qui nous prive d'un local pourtant si utile à l'occasion et qui nous aide à réaliser quelques rêves pour notre église tout en distrayant nos indiens.

Ce local a été aménagé au temps du Père Doucet et aux seuls frais de la Fabrique pour en faire une salle commune à l'usage des élèves du Couvent durant la mauvaise saison. Elle servait aussi quelque rarement pour de petites soirées. Lorsque Messieurs les Inspecteurs du Département venaient, ils étaient heureux d'avoir un local organisé pour réunir nos indiens. Les planchers, théâtre, l'éclairage électrique et les chaises ont été fournis et payés par la Fabrique. Pour ma part, je n'ai certes pas abusé de cette salle; car depuis mon séjour à Bersimis, nous n'avons fait qu'une séance préparée et donnée par nos indiens et canadiens. Le danger de feu n'existe à peu près pas; car l'éclairage est électrique, de plus nous ne permettons pas de fumer dans cette salle. Et lorsque nous avions des réunions, je restais moi-même pour inspecter cette salle après chaque réunion.

À la réception de votre lettre, nous étions à organiser une petite séance pour le mois de juin. Nous étions tous encouragés au succès de cette soirée, la seule probablement de l'année. Inutile de vous dire notre déception et nos regrets. Il me semble que vous pourriez me permettre de faire cette soirée étant avancé dans l'organisation. Je ne doute pas que votre bon cœur exaucera ma requête.

J'attends par le retour du courrier votre consolante réponse.

Cher Monsieur le Directeur, je n'ai jamais eu l'intention de vous blesser ou de vous offenser. J'ai toujours eu pour devise de travailler avec vous et le Département pour le plus grand bien de nos indiens. Je vous prie de croire que je serais heureux de vous faire une visite de bonne volonté et de vous faire honneur au Département. Vous pouvez compter sur mon soutien complet auprès du Département comme auprès de nos indiens.

J'ai eu le bonheur de vous rencontrer alors que je faisais mes études à l'Indiens du Golfe St-Laurent. Votre délicatesse et votre bonté pour nous avons été une circonstance ont laissé un précieux souvenir dans mon cœur. Nous nous souvenons encore de ces bons moments. Aussi j'en garde un cher souvenir. Il me serait très agréable de pouvoir vous revoir de nouveau et de causer ensemble sur des problèmes qui nous intéressent tous. Nous tenons à coeur également. Souhaitons que nos désirs se réalisent et que je le désire moi-même.

Veuillez agréer, Cher Monsieur le Directeur, avec la nouvelle année de mon entier dévouement, l'assurance de ma profonde considération et de ma plus haute gratitude.

Votre petit missionnaire de Bersimis,

MEMORANDUM

Mr. P. Phelan

RE: Bersimis Indian Day School grounds

I have just received correspondence from acting Indian Agent, Pierre Blouin, regarding different matters, one of which refers to the above.

Behind the school, the sewer ends in a gully and every year it washes away, the sides and end specially due to the amount of snow gathering at that point and coming from adjoining land; to avoid danger of school children from falling in and making the place more sanitary, there seem to be no alternative but filling the bottom with a few feet of coarse stones and covering up with earth, which would yet allow the sewerage to run through to the road ditch and prevent any accidents.

Agent Blouin estimates that it would cost between seventy-five and one hundred dollars to make a good job of it. Being aware of the situation, I recommend such improvement to be made as soon as possible, by Indian labor, providing funds are available.

Inspector of Indian Agencies
Ottawa, May 15, 1945.

Mr. Pierre Blouin, Indian Agent, Bersimis, Que.

Inspector Thibault has reported that improvements are required to the grounds around the Bersimis Indian Day School. He states that the cost of this work will be between $75.00 and $100.00. An expenditure not exceeding $100.00 is authorized. When the work is completed, you should advise this office and send a voucher for the amount expended. If possible, the cost should be kept below $100.00.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Ottawa, July 11, 1946.

Dear Sirs:

This is to confirm a conversation Mr. Doucet had with you a few days ago re a water closet combination.

We wish you to send two water closet combinations complete, to Mr. A.E. Desjardins, Acting Indian Agent, Bersimis, Quebec.

As these are for a school and as sanitary conditions at present, are very unsatisfactory we would appreciate it if you would ship these at the earliest possible date.

Kindly submit your account in triplicate, and send it to the Acting Indian Agent who will verify reception of the goods and forward it to us for payment.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

The Crane Company Limited,
148 Bank St.,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, July 11, 1946.

Mr. A.E. Desjardins, Acting Indian Agent, Bersimis, Que.,

I am confirming by this letter, the orders that Mr. Doucet gave you while in Bersimis some time ago.

Have the handy-man of the Rectory, disconnect the excessive radiation in the improvised Community Hall. See that the furnace is thoroughly cleaned every week when in use and purchase the necessary steel brushes to do this efficiently.

A gun and five gallons of caulking compound have been shipped from Ottawa. You will, no doubt, receive these in a short time, then, you will proceed to have the bricks pointed.

Two toilet bowls have been ordered but shipment is uncertain. As soon as you receive these, have them installed. Use them to replace those that have been removed from the Community Hall. This will require semi-partitions made from lumber. It will be necessary to pierce a door so that pupils can go from the present toilet room to the new installation.

It is understood with Reverend Father Langlois, O.M.I. that his handy-man will do this.

Send us the account for labor in the usual manner.

Kindly let us know if you have found a fireman for the school.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa, July 12, 1946.

Dear Father Langlois:

I have reason to believe that the organization of the school as we have discussed will be adopted. I wish, however, Right Reverend Bishop Labrie would let us know his views in this matter. You will recall that we wired him but to date I have not received a reply.

I hope your handy-man is able to disconnect the surplus radiators as we discussed. I have written to the Agent asking him to make a recommendation for the services of a fireman. You know whom we have in mind. I will be able to pay him $15.00 a month for twelve months. I wish he would begin to do the repair work before he takes up his duties as fireman, because due to Treasury Branch regulations we would be unable to pay him for repair work as he would already be receiving a salary. His salary would begin on October 1st.

With kindest personal regards, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

A.J. Doucet,
Rev.P. Langlois, O.M.I., Supervisor of Training.
c-o Bersimis Indian School,
Bersimis, Quebec.

Dear Mr Phelan,

When Mr Doucet visited Bersimis, we agreed that the school would be opened from the 15th of October till the 15th of next August. In order to be sure to do not run short of coal, he promised us to send 25 tons.

We did not receive anything yet and Mr Desjardins, acting agent, tells me that he has been sent a note that the coal for his own house had been ordered, but nothing was said about the school.

So I thought of writing you a word about it so that you would arrange that the school gets its coal in time before chilly weather.

Mr Doucet had also told us to order single desks instead of the double ones the children are using up to now. So I enclose this requisition of new desk-chairs. I thought of sending you this remission now instead of later as you will judge yourself when it is suitable to order them.

Ottawa, September 24, 1946.

Reverend Father:

At the time of my visit last June, I was under the impression that we had decided to appoint a janitor in the person of your handy-man. (1) There are no sewing machines, no tables, chairs, cooking stove and utensiles for the teaching of domestic arts.

(2) Moreover, there is absolutely nothing in the way of weaving machines, spinning-wheels and other articles necessary to teach the girls the art of weaving.

(3) There is really no library and on that account, the children are not taking any interest in reading. The purchase of one hundred volumes might be a good investment for this school, but before doing so, I think the Sisters ought to be consulted as there are stores in the Province of Quebec that make a specialty of providing useful and instructive reading for children.

(4) There is no typewriter and the Sister Superior is very desirous of securing one. Her claim is that it would be very useful in the preparation of special class material.

(5) I do not know whether it has been the practice of the Department to supply Gramophones or radio sets for day schools; but in a place as far away from civilization as Bersiamits is, such an instrument would certainly help a great deal in the conducting of classes and in creating in the minds of the Indian children, an interest in their work.

(6) The Sisters would also like to teach music to the boys and girls that have a talent for it, but there are no band instruments of any kind and there is not even an harmonium to use for this purpose. I noticed sometime ago that you were considering supplying some band instruments for a residential school. Why could not a day school, the size of Bersiamits, be gratified or given a sufficient number of instruments, so that the teaching of music would become a daily feature?

The above is submitted in the hope that you will be able to meet at least some of the wishes of the Sister Superior.

Thanking you in anticipation I remain,

Very truly yours,

J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.

Re: Bersiamits Indian Day School.

Attention: Mr. Philip Phelan.

My dear Mr. Phelan:

As mentioned over the phone, I am just back from a visit to the Bersiamits and Pointe Bleue Indian Day Schools. Both these institutions are in fairly good condition and are providing suitable education for the Indians that are attending them.

The Bersiamits Indian population is still very nomad and more than half of the people spend almost nine months in the bush, either working as woodsmen or hunting, trapping and fishing. This means that all the children in each family follow their parents and are therefore deprived of the educational benefits which they might otherwise receive by attending the Bersiamits Day School. Still, there are about fifty children who are in attendance and during the summer months, the Indians that wintered in the woods, come back to the village and for the summer period, some of the children attend school. As I have already stated in a previous letter, the only means of educating all these Indian children is the establishment of a residential school which would receive the children of the families who winter in the bush. For this purpose, a school with a maximum pupilage of one hundred would be quite sufficient.

Several improvements could be made in the present day school and I think that you will want to co-operate with the Sisters in this matter:

Re: Salaire de M. Doucet, chauffeur de l'école

Bien cher monsieur Doucet,

Le père Plourde m'a remis, lors de la réunion des missionnaires à Hull, la lettre en réponse à la mienne et que vous aviez adressée à Mgr Langlois, vicomte apostolique de Grouard. Comme vous voyez, la réponse à ma lettre est allée se promener loin avant de me parvenir; elle a presque traversé tout le Canada aller et retour.

J'aurais aimé vous faire au moins une petite visite lors de mon voyage à Hull; mais il m'a fallu m'en revenir le plus tôt possible avant la fermeture de la navigation, qui a été fermée le jour même de mon arrivée ici.

Je vous remercie beaucoup pour toute l'attention que vous avez portée à ma demande en faveur de M. Doucet, chauffeur à l'école indienne de Bersimis. Je suis satisfait de ce montant et M. Doucet de même.

Dès cette semaine, je soumettrai à M. Desjardins la feuille de compte à cet effet.

Votre tout dévoué en N.S. et M.I.

[Signature]

Paul Langlois O.M.I.

Monsieur Doucet,

Le dernier courrier m'a apporté votre lettre du 24 de ce mois. Je vous en remercie beaucoup. J'accepte aussi votre excuse de m'écrire en anglais; j'espère qu'un jour viendra où l'on se décidera à vous donner une sténographe bilingue.

Quant aux travaux à faire à l'école, voici ce qui a été fait jusqu'à date :

Vous nous avez demandé de démonter les calorifères qui étaient de trop dans la cave de l'école et de percez une porte de la chaufferie à la salle de théâtre. Nous avons fait ces travaux et vous en trouverez le compte dans cette enveloppe.

Il reste les travaux de réparation de la cheminée et des joints des briques. Le contracteur est venu la semaine dernière et il va bientôt nous envoyer les hommes pour faire ce travail; votre agent s'est entendu avec lui. C'est le même contracteur qui fera les travaux de réparation à notre église l'été prochain.

Vous m'avez demandé de lui faire faire des estimés pour replaster l'intérieur de votre école et enduire la brique à l'extérieur d'une couche de "Colorcrete" comme nous aurons à l'église. Il doit faire ces estimés et vous les transmettre par votre agent. Il garantit son travail; comme il doit vous donner tous ces détails, je ne vous en dirais pas plus long afin que ma lettre puisse partir ce matin.

Votre très dévoué en N.S. et M.I.

P.S. M. Doucet avait d'abord refusé de prendre le chauffage de l'école; je viens de réussir à le lui faire accepter; mais il aimerait bien que vous lui donniez $18.00 par mois au lieu de $15.00; je crois que le Département pourrait facilement faire cela.

Ottawa, May 9, 1947.

Memorandum:

MR. FREDLAN.

Repair to Bersimis Indian Day School.

I interviewed Mr. St. Laurent and discussed with him the condition of the Bersimis School. I also interviewed Mr. Brochu, who is the Canadian representative for colorcrete. I visited some of the work which was done with colorcrete. I was especially interested in a hospital in Quebec city which has been covered with this material for five or six years. The officials of this hospital "L'Hopital Enfant Jesus" are preparing to have other sections of the building covered with colorcrete in the near future. To me this indicates complete satisfaction with this process. I am satisfied that if the walls of the Bersimis school were covered with colorcrete the unsatisfactory condition as existing today would be rectified. I would suggest that the contract be given to Mr. St. Laurent. In his letter of September 7, 1946, he estimated the cost of covering the exterior of the school at $2200.00.

To renew the plaster of the exterior of the school Mr. St. Laurent submitted a price at $2380.00. His plan was to replace all the plaster. Apparently these were the directions he received. However, Mr. St. Laurent admits that the plaster could be repaired satisfactorily without being so drastic. I suggested to him that this should be left in abeyance until the school could be gone over with him before he undertakes the repair of the interior plaster. I believe that I am safe in estimating
that the repair of the plaster in this school would not exceed $500.00. May I suggest that this arrangement be confirmed in an official letter to Mr. St. Laurent.

A.J. Doucet,
Supervisor, Training Division.

Ottawa, July 22, 1947.

Memorandum:

MR. PHELAN.

Re: Bersimis Indian Day School.

With further reference to my memorandum of May 9, 1947, I have interviewed Mr. St. Laurent and together we visited the school premises. There is considerable repair to be done to the plaster in the classrooms and in the teacher's quarters. This should, however, not exceed four hundred square yards of plaster. Mr. St. Laurent is ready to undertake this work at a cost of $1.25 per square yard. It is rather difficult to set an exact amount of yardage as in demolishing the damaged plaster more or less is liable to require replacement. I would suggest that the agreement should read that Mr. St. Laurent be awarded a price of $1.25 per square yard for approximately three hundred and fifty square yards.

We have revised the prices for colorcrete and have come to an agreement with Mr. St. Laurent that he will undertake the work for $1990.00. This will comprise of two coats of colorcrete to the brick siding and two coats of paint on the trim and windows.

A further expenditure will be necessary to decorate the entire interior of the school and teacher's quarters. Mr. St. Laurent is agreeable to give the entire inside one coat of sealer and two coats of paint for the sum of $500.00.
You are aware that this is a three-room school with two hallways and a teacher's residence which consists of a kitchen, dining-room, living-room, four bed-rooms and a bathroom.

There are insufficient toilet accommodation for the pupils of this school. There are but two toilets for ninety-six pupils. Mr. St. Laurent can obtain the material required. Two toilet bowls complete and a wash basin should be installed where they had been before removal many years ago. The equipment will mean an expenditure of about $150.00.

I would suggest that Mr. St. Laurent be awarded this contract and be so advised as soon as possible in order that he may make the arrangements necessary to have this work completed before the re-opening of the classrooms in October.

A.J. Doucet,
Supervisor, Training Division.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Bersimis Indian Day School

In memorandum dated May 13th, 1947, you authorized an expenditure of $2,200.00 at the above mentioned school in order to cover the outside walls of the school with colorcrete.

We also received a quotation from Mr. St. Laurent for plastering and other repairs required to this school but as his tender was high, Mr. Doucet was sent to Bersimis to decide what work was necessary.

It was found that the school needed interior plastering and repairing and after discussing the matter thoroughly with Mr. Doucet, Mr. St. Laurent offered to do the plastering for $615.00 and decorating the interior and fixing the chimney for $1,515.00.

Originally Mr. St. Laurent requested $4,580.00 for both the interior and exterior repairs and subsequently reduced this tender to $4,190.00. Of this amount $2,200.00 has already been authorized.

We would appreciate it if we could have your authority to pay the balance of $1,990.00. Previous authority was not obtained for this amount as we were not certain that the work was definitely required until Mr. Doucet went to Bersimis.

Mr. St. Laurent was doing other work in the neighborhood and consequently the urgent repairs had to receive immediate attention as otherwise it would have been impossible to secure anyone to do the work.
The Indian agent states that the school is now in first class condition and should not require further repairs for some time.

Director.

Mr. Scott,

A request has been received for the establishment of a school for the Indian children at Brennan Lake in the Kippewa country. This request was made by Joseph Miness, an Indian, who stated that there are thirteen families with thirty-three children, eighteen of whom are of school age.

He states that there is no white school within thirty miles and that they are receiving no education whatever. He also states that there is no building suitable for a school-room.

Schools are conducted for the summer months only at several points in the Kippewa and Temiskaming districts.

In this case it would be necessary to provide a building in which to conduct the school. Mr. Young strongly recommends the opening of a school. He states that the children are bright and intelligent and that the parents would see that they took advantage of the school, should one be opened. There is no reserve at this point. He does not state to what band these Indians belong. Some arrangement should be made for the education of these Indian children and it will first be necessary to provide a school building. I will be pleased to have your instructions regarding the request for a school for the benefit of these children.

To The Secretary of The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 10th Inst., regarding the establishment of an Indian school at Brennan Lake, I found the statement that there are thirteen families and eighteen children of school age to be correct. They are all full blood Indians and are one of the Algonquin bands. Brennan Lake is known on the map as Sairs Lake. A man named Sairs, long ago, lived there, and the lake was named after him. After, when the late J. B. Latour lumbered in that district, his agent was a man named Brennan and the lake has since been known as Brennan Lake. The McLaughlin Brothers of Amprior have a farm and Depot there. I made inquiries there about the erection of a school building, and was assured by Mr. Lindsay, agent for the McLaughlin Brothers, that he would assist them by providing free teams in getting out logs for their building and in other ways. I think if they had a school during the summer months, say six months in a year, it would be sufficient.

I expect to be in Ottawa the last of this week, and will call on you and take a map with me and show you the exact location of Wolf Lake and Brennan Lake. I may say, however, there is no accurate map of that portion of northern Quebec.

Yours truly,

M. James
MEMORANDUM

Mr. Scott,

Dr. James of Mattawa, who was in the office yesterday enquiring about the establishment of a school for the Indian children at Brennan or Sairs Lake, stated that these children were all Indians, their parents residing permanently at this point. The Indians are employed mostly by the McLaughlin Brothers who have a mill and large timber limit at this point.

He states that the lumber company and the Indians will erect a suitable building and provide desks, stove and fuel. I told him that when the building was ready the Department would be prepared to pay the salary of a teacher and furnish the school material required. He stated that he thought that if the school were conducted six months each year, from the 1st of May until the end of October, that that would be sufficient, at least until such time as would be seen how the attendance kept up and what success was met with. He will arrange with the lumber company and the Indians for the completion of the building and getting it ready for occupation.

The map of the district showing the location of the proposed school was left by Dr. James and is hereunder for file.

A school is required at this point as the children at present receive no education. I was unable to consult either yourself or Mr. McKenzie in this matter, it being lunch time when the doctor called, and I hope you will approve of the action taken by me. The salaries paid the teachers in the summer schools in the Kippawa District is $75.00 per month and we would likely have to pay the same in this case.

Sir:

In reply to official letter No.35-6-1 of the 4th inst. in reference to the school at Brennan Lake, I beg to report:

The work on the building of this schoolhouse was commenced last summer, at the time when the missionary priest made his visit to Brennan Lake. After the priest left the work stopped, and was not recommenced till he made his visit this summer. The building is of hewed pine logs, with mortised corners, and is 20 ft. wide by 30 ft. long, and when finished will be a good substantial building. Last summer the walls were partially built, and there remained about 4 rounds of logs left from the required height. I reached Brennan Lake a couple of days after the departure of the priest, and upon my arrival I found that the walls of the building were completed, ready for putting up the rafters for the roof. The lumber required for the roof and floor is on the ground, also the doors and windows, and the roofing felt. There are 8 windows 3 for each side, and 2 for the front, one each side of the door. There were 5 or 6 Indians working at the building during my visit, and they claim that they will have the school ready for occupation on the 5th of September, but I am very doubtful whether they will or not. The Indian in charge of the work is Jee Tenassie, and he is to report to me on the progress of the work, and to let me know when the building is completed, as I have informed them that there will be no teacher sent to Brennan Lake till they have a school ready for her to teach in. There is no excuse for any delay in the building of the school, as all that is required is the labour, and the materials required are all on the ground and the priest had left a sum of money at McLachlan's Depot, to pay these working on the building at the rate of $2.00 per day, and there are quite a few Indians around there doing nothing. The horses and the rigging required are furnished by the McLachlan Lumber Co., free of charge, as also was the lumber, and their Agent has promised to send a carpenter to work on the school for a few days to put in the doors and windows, and other skilled labour required, also without any charge. So if the Indians of Brennan Lake do not soon have a good school-house built, it is because they do not want one.

The school was conducted during the last school year at the house of one of the Indians, and it seems that from information given me while at Brennan Lake, was far from satisfactory. The school teacher must have put up with a lot of hardship and inconvenience, and did well to stay there till the end of the term. The scholars made fine, clear progress during the year, many of them being able to read and write fairly well. I visited all the Indian homes in the vicinity and saw most of the children's schoolbooks, and I must say that for one year they did remarkably well.
The Indians are pleased to hear that Miss Sauve is going back again, and I have succeeded in getting a better boarding place for her. I have arranged with Joe Monasse to board her this next year, and she will be better there than she was last winter. It is no use of the teacher proceeding to Brennan Lake until the school is completed, and I think it would be better to advise Miss Sauve not to go until she is notified by me that the school is ready for occupation.

Regarding the equipment for this school I beg to say that with the exception of the blackboard shipped last winter, there is none on hand. To equip this school there would need to be provided an outfit similar to the one authorized in official letter No. 35-6-5 of the 6th of Sept., 1921 for the school at Hunter's Point, the only difference being that 15 desks would be sufficient, and the blackboard has already been provided. I will make a further report on hearing from Monasse, and I made it very plain to the Indians that they must finish the school house at once, and that the teacher would not arrive until it is finished.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Sir:

Sir,

When the June quarter return of the Brennan Lake Indian Day School was received, it was noted that the teacher had closed the school on June 11th. As the Department had not given any permission to her to do this, we wrote to her and requested her reasons for doing so.

She replied and stated that she kept the school open during the Christmas and Easter holidays, also on Labour Day, King's Birthday and Empire Day. She further stated that if she had not closed the school on June 11th, it would have been impossible for her to reach Kipawa as the logs in the river would have prevented navigation.

The Department does not favour having the school open on recognized holidays and would prefer that this procedure be not followed but that the school be kept open until June 30th. Please let me have your views in the matter and state if it would be difficult for the teacher to get away from the school if it were kept open until the end of the school term.

Your obedient servant,

Memorandum:

THE HONOURABLE THE SUPERINTENDENT GENERAL,-

For some years past, the Department has conducted an Indian Day School at Brennan's Lake, 60 miles east of Kippewa, in the electoral district of Pontiac, Que.

There are two Indian families in the vicinity of this school. They have 8 children, and, in addition, 8 half-breed children attend. This makes a total enrolment of 16.

The teacher who was in charge of the school last year, Miss Mary Conroy, left at the end of May, stating that the two Indian families were making matters so uncomfortable for her that she did not wish to remain longer in charge of the school.

In view of the attitude of the two Indian families, the Indian Agent and the Parish Priest have expressed the opinion that it might be advisable to leave the school closed for a year. On the other hand, if this was done, it would mean that the Indian children would not receive any education for that period, and, for this reason, I consider that it would be advisable to re-open the school and issue definite instructions to the Agent to warn the Indians that they must not interfere with the teacher.

A Catholic teacher is required for this school, and, if you concur in continuing it in operation, I consider that Miss Helena Carter, of Corkery, Ont., has the required qualifications. Her application for appointment as teacher of an Indian school was forwarded to the Department with Mr. Buskard's memorandum of the 21st instant.

Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Sir,

I have been advised by the agent to write directly to you. I am the teacher at the Indian Day School here. This is my third year.

Despite every possible economy I find my salary of $75 per month insufficient. I have to support my mother and young brother at home. Last year we purchased only the barest necessities of life, here and at home, and yet at the end of the year I did not have sufficient funds to last through the summer.

In making this humble petition I do not wish to dictate to you. However, I am justified in expecting a salary which will allow me and my dependents to live comfortably during the year and also to enable me to set aside a small sum in case of sickness or other emergency.

I humbly request that my salary be increased to $90 per month. This will not be anything more than a minimum family wage from a model employer, the Government of Canada.

October 15th, 1936.

I think Green Lake school is not difficult as the pupils require, only patience and not to be rushed beyond what they are capable of doing.

Thanking you for your taking the interest in this, I remain yours truly,

M. Alouette

Dear Mr. Caza:

I received your letter of July 20th, and since have been offered our own home school. He possesses a First Class Elementary Certificate in French and English, and I am sure he would do very well there for this year, as I would not spare any effort in helping.
him all I can.

Dear Sir:

Your suggestion that Joseph Duquette be appointed teacher at the Brennan Lake School is acceptable to the Department, provided that his employment is satisfactory to the church authorities and approved by them. Sir-

I beg to enclose herewith a letter received from Mr. Joseph Duquette former teacher at Brannan Lake. I am not very much up to what could be done in the present circumstances.

Rev. Father Martel o.m.i. who was returning from Kipawa and on his way to Rouyn, stopped here yesterday and informed me that a Miss Beauchesne living not far from Kipawa and having her diploma was to make her application for the position of teacher at the Hunter Point School. As soon as I will hear from her, I will send her application to the Department.

Rev. Father Martel informed me that he was expecting news from Chapeau about a teacher for Brannan Lake but it is I believe very doubtful and if it was possible to get a teacher it would be advisable not to wait any longer. Dear Sir:

Re: Brennan Lake Indian Day School

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 2nd instant and to state that the Department is not prepared to employ Joseph Duquette as teacher of the above-noted school.

Men of military age are not eligible for positions in the public service, unless suffering from physical disabilities and we have not, at any time, asked for exemptions in the case of Indian day school teachers. You should discuss the vacancy at this school with Rev. Father Martel. It is just possible that he may have in mind a teacher who would be prepared to take the position.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

OTTAWA, September 8, 1922.

Madam:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 5th instant, with reference to the amount of salary paid you as teacher of the Brennan's Lake Indian Day School from October, 1921, to June 30, 1922.

There are 200 teaching days in the school year, and you were promised salary at the rate of $350.00, which is equal to $1.75 per day. The returns received from you show that from October, 1921, to June 30, 1922, the school was in operation for 176 days. This would make the amount due you 176 x $1.75 = $308.00. The Department has already paid you $315.00. There is, therefore, no further amount due you. In fact, as you can see from the above, you have been overpaid.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

You should take this matter up with Rev. Father Evain, and it is hoped that either he or yourself will be able to nominate the services of a qualified teacher in due time. Please forward the name, qualifications and experience of the teacher recommended by Father Evain and yourself.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,

Sir:

I have your letter of the 17th instant, informing the Department that Miss Mary Conroy has been appointed teacher of the Brennan Lake Indian Day School and that she has proceeded to the school and taken up duties. It is noted that she has a first class elementary diploma and has had ten years' experience in teaching.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will approve of her appointment, with salary at the rate of $75 per teaching month. It is noted that she intends to teach during the month of July to make up for the time lost through the closing of the school and the difficulty she had in travelling to the school. The Department cannot pay any part of her travelling expenses, but will allow her salary from the date she left home to proceed to the school. If Father Evain advanced any money to pay her expenses, he should look to her for repayment.

The Department is placing an order with the Government Stationery Office here to send, at the earliest possible date, the textbooks asked for by Miss Conroy in the letter which you forwarded.

It is noted that you have authorized the teacher to purchase a broom, pail and soap. You should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure, when payment will be made.

It is hoped that Miss Conroy will meet with every success in her work at the Brennan Lake School.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir:

Memorandum.

Mr. Scott:

The Rev. Father Evain, Roman Catholic Missionary for the Lake Temiskaming country, has been instrumental in having erected log school houses at Brennan's Lake and Hunter's Point. The Rev. Gentleman collected what funds he could from the Indians interested, and the unskilled labour was performed gratis.

The Department promised no assistance in connection with the building of these schools. We equipped them with desks, etc., and are now paying teachers; both cruises are flourishing this academic year.

Father Evain has used some missionary money for hardware, doors, windows, etc., and has now submitted accounts of $228.05 and $136.93 for the Hunter's Point and Brennan's Lake Schools, respectively. The Department appoints the teachers and is conducting the schools through the office of Mr. Agent Lewis. They are not strictly missionary activities, and I would be pleased to have your authority to pay these accounts.

Supt. of Indian Education.
OTTAWA, Dec. 15th, 1922.

Sir:

The Department has received the enclosed accounts from Rev. Father I. Evain for material supplied and paid for by him in connection with the building of the schools at Hunter's Point (R.C.) and Brennan's Lake. The Department promised no assistance in connection with the erection of these buildings. Father Evain collected all the funds he could from the Indians interested, and the unskilled labour was performed gratis. We supplied furnishings, such as desks, blackboards, stove, etc.

We are favourably disposed to assist Father Evain to the amount of the enclosed accounts, and, if you consider that they are reasonable and a fair charge, I should be pleased if you would attach them to proper voucher forms, certify the same and forward to the Department in order that payment can be made.

Kindly give this matter your early attention.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,

Dear Sir,

I was on a visit to Brennan Lake Indian mission last week, which mission is served by Rev. Father Evans O.M.I., Indian missionary, and myself, and I found the school there in very poor condition. The teacher Miss Mary Daniels tells me that she has letters from you re this school, so I am writing you to see what can be done to improve matters.

The school when built from timber was used, so that now the plaster used to chink the building is all falling out because the timber has dried and leaves large cracks, and one can see daylight through the building. The interior has never been finished, and a ceiling is needed as it is impossible to heat the building as it is. Speaking of heating there never was a stove sent to this school.
So they have been using second-hand
text by some of the Indians, and at
present are without one. So you can see
that if matters are not looked into in the
near future we will be obliged to close
the school for the winter months, which
would be too bad, as success is about
in sight for this school.

I have another mission, Kipawa,
which is in need of a teacher. There are at
present 10 Indian children ready for school,
and a number of younger ones for future
years. We have a good school built there
with desks installed, a gift of some Indians
who took pity on these children. So if you
would give me the authority to engage a
teacher for this school, and the Govt. send the
books required, it would place our Indian
missions in very good condition.

Please let me know soon a possible
what can be done at these two missions, as I will
be returning to visit them about 15th Oct. and
will be in a position to arrange matters.

I remain, Yours Truly,

Rev. E. A. Litang.
Ottawa, September 25, 1924.

Reverend Sir,

I have your letter of the 22nd instant, with reference to the condition of the school building at Brennan Lake.

In reply I beg to say that Mr. W. H. Lewis, Indian Agent, North Temiskaming, has been requested to have the building made comfortable for the winter months. He was instructed to have the material forwarded and arrange for the work in putting in a ceiling in the classroom and any other repairs required was also to be attended to.

The agent was further instructed to purchase a stove of a type suitable to meet the requirements. He was informed that the Department was anxious to make this school building as comfortable as possible for the teacher and the pupils during the coming winter and requested to have the work done as soon as possible. It might be advisable for you to consult Mr. Lewis and ascertain what steps he has taken to have these instructions carried out.

You will be advised later as to the decision arrived at regarding your request for the establishment of a school at your mission at Kipawa.

Your obedient servant,

In reply to official letter no 35-6-5 of Jan, the 22nd, I beg to inform the Department that the 2 barrels of lime bought for the Brannan Lake School cost $7.16 delivered to Kippawa. It was shipped in time to be taken to Brannan Lake 3 weeks before the closing of navigation. The trouble was that the boat of Capt J. Cunningham that use to make a weekly trip to Red Pine Chute, 15 miles from Brannan Lake stop running altogether.

Miss Conroy asked Jos Robinson to get this lime with his gasoline boat. This man had no money and bought gasoline at the name of the teacher and at the same time he bought material to be mixed with the lime. This cost $1.26 and was paid for by the teacher, this was not authorized but they claim it is necessary to make a good job.

It would have been more in order for Miss Conroy to fix a price for the transportation of this lime and get a receipt from J. Robinson and have nothing to do with the gasoline but he did not tell her that he had no money before he left and it was certainly not her fault, I suppose this Indian thought also that he was doing well in getting the material to be mixed with the lime. The cost for transportation is not too high for the distance from Kippawa to Red Pine Chute is 45 miles and from there is a portage and 15 more miles on the river to Brannan Lake. There was no bad will on the part of any one and I would recommend that the amount of $4.14 be paid to Miss Conroy and I will advise her how transportation should be paid for in the future.

A.F. MacKenzie Esq.
Secretary.

Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith a voucher amounting to $12.00 in favour of Miss Marjorie Duquette, teacher at the Brannan Lake Indian Day School.

The distance from Brannan Lake to Kippawa is 60 miles, but the teacher has paid too much for that trip because I am sure that Miness must have had some business of his own at Kippawa.

Miness told the teacher that he had to make a special trip to get these school books that she needed badly and could not go for less. This was done I believe during the month of March. I asked the teacher not to pay any more than $5.00 for such a trip in the future but the best is to get the material need for all winter before the freezing of the lakes.

Your obedient servant,

Notre Dame du Nord Que, Aug. 27, 1938

Sir-

I would be pleased if the Department will authorize an expenditure of $100.00 for repairs of the Brannan Lake Indian Day School. This would be to cover material and labour.

I am informed that paper is needed for a new roof, for the outside and the inside. 250 lbs of lime will also be needed, window glasses and paint.

It is possible that it will cost less than the amount mentioned if it does not cost too much for transportation. Sometimes it is hard to get anyone to transport the material from Kippawa to Brannan a distance of about 60 miles with a long portage. Kindly advise as soon as possible.

Your obedient servant

Indian Agent

T.R.L. MacInnes Esq.

Ottawa.

To the Superintendent
of Indian Affairs
Ottawa.

This is to request the Department of Indian Affairs to help to the construction of a residence for the teacher of the Brennen Lake day school, Bemiskaming Co., in the agency of Mr. J. Caza.

With the sum of $400.00, I figure to be able to build and furnish the said residence. Nobody, in the locality is, any more, in the position to board the teacher.

I must say that the new teacher, Miss Conroy, whom I have seen in duty during this month of July at Brennen, is giving complete satisfaction to the children and to the parents.

And I am
your humble servant,

Madam:

Rev. Father E. Blanchin has nominated you to take a position at the Barriere Summer Indian Day School. This school will be conducted for a period of three months, and the salary allowed will be at the rate of $90 per teaching month. We do not, however, pay the travelling expenses of teachers.

Your obedient servant,

Bush School
Extract from Inspector E. Lippen's report on the Caughnawaga schools.

I consider that the experiment of opening a new school at the place called the "Bush" has been successful beyond every expectation, and that Mrs. Bovey, who has ten years experience as a teacher, and knows the Iroquois language, is the right person there. You will see on page 10 that several pupils between 14 and 16 and above 16 frequented that school; their chief object was to learn arithmetic and reading, and they behaved very properly. Also the general attendance was very fair under the circumstances. So I hope you will build there a good spacious, hygienic school house for the month of September next.
To the Secretary,
School of Indian Department,
Ottawa.

Sir:

Reverting to the disappointment of the Bush people, especially myself, at not having the school and dwelling houses built erected this year, I beg to acquaint the Department that I endured some hardship and discomfort during last winter so much so that I then made my mind that I
would not on any condition pass another winter in the upper school house, but, owing to heavy pressures from the Bush people on several occasions and the two men came forward and offered to give the Department a school site if I remained with them. Under these circumstances I consented to continue the school.

I have only two rooms for my use, one is a kitchen, living and dining room combined and the other a bed-room.

There is another unmistakably disagreeable and that is the foul air from the class-room to the upper rooms.
I am compelled to have our rooms opened until we felt the effects of the cold air from without. I think Mr. Benson can vouch for my words. He knows the small space I and my family have to occupy.

Taking it altogether, I would ask the Department to grant me an increase in salary, and I pray that my request will be favorably considered.

I have the honor to be Sir,

your obedient servant,

Annie Beausoleil.

The Deputy Superintendent General,

Mr. Agent Blain reports that Mrs. Beauvais, teacher of the Bush school, refuses to receive the children of white tenants on the reserve as pupils in her school. I have been going to the Caughnawaga country school since its opening & have attended faithfully every school day as I am very desirous of obtaining an education.

With reference to the copy of an order from Mrs. A. Beauvais, teacher of the Bush School on the Caughnawaga Reserve, in favour of Mr. Joseph Dubuc for the sum of $100.00 to be paid out of her salary for the current quarter I beg to say that I do not see how Mrs. Beauvais can pay $100.00 out of her salary, even if she admits the debt and acknowledges the genuineness of the order in his favour, as she is under an agreement with the Department to pay for her daughter's schooling at the Aylmer Convent, which will make quite a hole in the $100.00 the Department will owe her at the end of this quarter. If Mrs. Beauvais admits her indebtedness and expresses her wish to pay Dubuc I think that he should be willing to have the debt liquidated by installments, as I do not consider that she is in a posi-
tion to pay $100.00 at one time. The Department has never held itself responsible for the collection of debts from Indian teachers and I do not see why an exception should be made in favour of Mr. Dubuc.

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

Mr. Agent Brosseau, in his report for the month of June last, on the Caughnawaga Bush School, stated that the walls of the school are in bad condition and as Mr. Chene of this Department was going to Caughnawaga I asked him to be good enough to report on the condition of the class-room of this school.

He reports that the whole of the plastering has fallen to pieces and that there are no traces of painting left on the woodwork of the building. He says that the doors and the windows are in great need of repair. He recommends that, if the Department should decide to repair the walls and ceiling of this building, it be done with 7/8 inch V joint sheeting, instead of plastering; this being more economical and better adapted for the class-room.

I visited this school myself in May, 1913, and found the plaster on the walls in very bad condition. I
brought a sample of the plaster back to the Department and it showed that there was not enough hair mixed with the mortar to make it stick to the lathes. Mr. Letourneau was authorized to have this attended to, but he apparently failed to do so.

I would suggest that Mr. Chene be authorized to have the school put in repair when he next visits the Caughnawaga Reserve.

Martin Benson

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

With reference to Mrs. Beauvais' application for an increase of salary I beg to say that she has had charge of the Bush School on the Caughnawaga Reserve since it was opened in 1906 and prior to that time she acted as assistant in the Girls' School from 1895. When she commenced teaching she was paid $150.00 a year, with increases from time to time, bringing her salary up to $450.00 at present. She has been in receipt of this amount since the first of April, 1914. In addition to her salary she is supplied with a free house.

There are twenty-five children enrolled at this school, with an average attendance of twenty-one for the past year.

Mrs. Beauvais has a fair education and Mr. Lippens, who formerly inspected this school, reported that she managed the school with tact and zeal and that she is well liked and respected by the pupils and parents. She maintains an excellent average attendance and is a successful teacher in the lower grades.

I
I have visited her school on two or three occasions and consider that she is entitled to an increase of at least $50.00.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 4th instant, submitting an estimate of the cost of labour and painting of the Caughnawaga Bush School.

In reply I beg to say that the Department has decided to do this work by day labour and you may appoint Mr. Louis Jacob as working foreman at 30¢ an hour. The lumber, the cost of which should not exceed you estimate, of $80.00, may be purchased and delivered by Joseph Dubuc of St. Isidore. You may also purchase a sufficient quantity of paint at the price stated in your letter, namely, $10.50 per hundred pounds and the necessary oil at 90¢ per gallon.

You should forward certified accounts in duplicate at the end of each week for the labour and you will be good enough to see that the work is done as quickly as possible, so that the school may re-open on time.

It would be well to request Mrs. Beauvais to let you know whether the work is being done as expeditiously as possible.

Your obedient servant

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 7th instant, with enclosure, relative to the desks which were furnished by Mr. L.G. St. Jean for use at the Caughnawaga Bush School; and in reply I beg to say that the explanations furnished with regard to the advance in prices, namely from $8.35 to $10.00 and from $6.65 to $10.55, are not satisfactory. Mr. St. Jean has stated that the change in prices was consequent upon the fact that the lady teacher choose double desks to match those in the school. The prices originally quoted according to your letter of the 6th August were $8.35 for small double desks and $6.65 for large double desks. I may therefore say that if the teacher choose double desks prices on such articles had already been quoted. It may also be stated that the Department received quotations of prices from another firm whereby small double desks would be furnished at $8.20 and large double desks at $8.50, which prices covered delivery. In view of the fact that the articles required could have been obtained at the prices stated, Mr. St. Jean will understand that the Department would not be justified in paying him $10.00 and $10.55 when articles, such as required of equal quality to those which he provided, could be obtained at the prices above shown. I may also say it is expected that when an order is given to a firm, the said firm will abide by the prices which they have quoted, and not advance them when delivery of goods is made. In view of the foregoing the cheque No. 1311 drawn for $34.00 is returned herewith.

Your obedient servant,

J.M. Brosseau Esq.,

Ottawa, December 29, 1920.

MEMORANDUM

Mr. Scott,

Mrs. A. Beauvais, teacher of the Bush School on the Caughnawaga Reserve, who visited the Department yesterday, requested that she be granted an increase in her salary from the first of the New Year. She is at present receiving $450.00 per annum, together with the bonus at the rate of $150.00.

Mrs. Beauvais has been in the service of the Department as teacher in this school for fourteen years and has had no increase in salary since March 1st, 1914. She has no professional qualifications, but Mr. Public School Inspector Gilman, in a recent report of inspection, states that she is fairly successful in her work and that the management and general discipline at the school were good and that progress was being made. There is an enrolment of 24 pupils, with an average attendance of 18.

Her daughter, who is teacher at the St. Isidore Road School, is paid a salary at the rate of $500.00 per annum. She has what is known as a Commercial Certificate. There is an enrolment of 26 pupils, with an average attendance of 20 at this school.

I would beg to recommend that Mrs. Beauvais be granted an increase of $50.00, in view of the fact that she has given faithful service and has had no increase for nearly seven years. I shall be pleased to have your decision in the matter.

Composition:
Esau and Jacob.

Esau was born first and Jacob the second. Esau became a hunter and a husbandman but Jacob was a shepherd. One day Isaac told his son Esau to go into the fields to get him a savory dish to eat. But Rebecca heard what they were talking about and told Jacob to get two kids that she might cook it; first and Jacob would give it to his father so as he would get a blessing. Isaac called Jacob and said the voice is the voice of Jacob but the hands are the hands of Esau. So he blessed Jacob and ate the savory dish which Rebecca had cooked. When Esau returned back from the chase he had caught something and when he heard what had happened he became very angry and told his brother it would happen to him something. Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter dated 11th instant with regard to a one month's leave of absence granted by the Department to Mrs. A. Beauvais, teacher of the Bush school at Caughnawaga.

I beg to point out that at several occasions since over a year ago, many complaints have been made through my office by a few parents of pupils against the teacher Mrs. A. Beauvais. These complaints are particularly made by non-indians who are however authorized tenants of the various Holdings situated in the vicinity of Bush school. I am told by these parents that Mrs. Beauvais has entirely neglected the education of their children and that her reason of doing so is that she is not supposed to give her attention to the "pea-soups" but only to the Indians.

I am also informed that the assistant-teacher Rosy-Ann Jacobs who was replacing Mrs. Beauvais during her frequent absences of the school year 1926-1927 is incompetent and that she has the habit of releasing her pupils in order to admit her lovers into the school.

On account of her old age and almost blindness, I beg to suggest that Mrs. A. Beauvais be compelled to give her resignation in order that a competent teacher be appointed at Bush School.

Memorandum:

DR. SCOTT,

Mrs. A. Beauvais, who has taught for the Department continuously from September, 1895, has been retired as from the 30th ultimo. It is desired to deal as generously as possible in her case.

Prior to 1924, three teachers of Indian day schools, who had given long service, were superannuated under the Calder Act. The provisions of this Act are no longer effective. In addition, seven teachers were given from three to six months' retiring leave, and, as far as I am aware, these payments were not questioned.

The Superannuation Act of 1924 evidently changed the situation. You will remember that the Department decided it was not proper to admit our teachers to the privileges enjoyed by a permanent Civil Servant. This action was taken for good and sufficient reasons, which still obtain. In 1925, however, when we granted four months' retiring leave to Levi Doxtator, the Auditor General wrote: "Retiring leave with pay may be granted only by the Civil Service Board and must not extend beyond 60 days. I shall be obliged if you will let me know the authority under which this payment to Levi Doxtator has been made." The Department replied in part: "I regret that I can find no authority in this connection". I believe the only adequate authority would have been a special vote.

From 1924 to 1927, several teachers of Indian day schools, who had served the Department faithfully, received two months' retiring leave. These were not questioned. I now believe, however, that these payments of two months' gratuity from 1924 to 1927 were really without adequate authority. Section 73 of the Civil Service Regulations makes no provision for retiring leave in the case of those who have not been given permanent status.

Pursuant to an Order in Council in June, 1927, concerning superannuation regulations, I find that there was an additional Order passed on July 4th of that year (P.C. 5/1316). This gives authority for retiring leave to "temporary employees who have been employed in permanent positions under departmental authority since prior to the 24th of May, 1916, but whose permanent status has never been confirmed". The retiring leave mentioned is as provided by Section 73 of the Civil Service Regulations as extended by the Order in Council. Section 73 allows 2 months' retiring
leave, and, in the case of persons who are being re-
tired under the provisions of the Superannuation and
Retirement Act, 1906, or under the provisions of
Section 5, Subsection a I and a II, of the C. S. S. A.,
1927, retiring leave as follows:

10 to 15 years continuously - 3 months,
15 " 20 " " - 4 " ;
20 " 25 " " - 5 " ;
25 years or over " - 6 " .

I believe it is quite in order, under authority
of this Order in Council, to give retiring leave of from
one to six months to teachers of Indian day schools who
have been in our employ prior to May 24, 1918. With
your concurrence, I propose to allow Mrs. Beaureais six
months' gratuity. She has taught continuously for 36 years.

In the case of those teachers who were not
employed before May 24, 1918, but who now or in the
future have given 8, 10 or 12 years' service; there
appears to be no authority for even 2 months' retiring
leave, but, as we have always granted such without
official criticism from any source, I think we can
safely continue the practice for worthy teachers.

Russell T. Perrier
Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Madam:

Mr. Hoey

RE : Bush school house and teacher's residence at Caughnawaga, Que.

The question of a location to take care of the extension of the commercial weaving and artcraft has, I understand, been discussed; the teaching to pupils could then be left in the school itself.

As a result of my conversation with Miss Moodie, a few days previous to my visit at Caughnawaga, I went over to look at the two buildings above mentioned.

I found that the inside and outside woodwork is in good condition, doors and windows are as good as new and, if some careful person took charge of dismantling the two buildings, we would certainly have sufficient lumber to erect a good sized building, to locate our commercial weaving plant, and also provide for supervisor's quarters on the upper floor as well as having plenty of space for stock and other purposes.

The buying of the two buildings, as they stand is not practical, due to the roads being so narrow and their condition. Fences would have to be taken down and it would certainly be a long and expensive job. The railroad underpass is too small to allow the passage of any of the buildings, and in my opinion, the location of the buildings on this side of the underpass could not be considered as favorable for our purpose.

The only alternative is, to carefully demolish the two buildings and use the lumber to build on the space in front of the school, near the Indians agent's office, and a little on the side so as not to obstruct the view of the school and as close to the Highway as possible, in order that all tourist passing the school gate, could come and see the Indians at work; a small office on the ground floor could also be used for exhibiting finished goods and sales could be made right there.

Aware of the mentality of the Indians in that section of Bush school, may I suggest that immediate steps be taken to demolish the two said buildings, otherwise we may soon find that these people would begin to break in and remove windows, doors, etc., as they may require them to repair their own houses.

For the spending of a few hundred dollars, here is a chance to improve our handicraft business without great expense, besides filling a long felt need to divide the teaching and commercial ends of our enterprise and give it a further expansion, for the benefit of the girls who have learned their trade while at school.

Changes in the personnel of the school has caused a different situation, and conditions are not what they were two years ago, and I feel that we should grasp the opportunity to use materials already paid for, which would only deteriorate or disappear in the very near future. Mr. Busk carried out the inspection on August 21st and 22nd last, and reports conditions to be as follows:

The site selected by Indian Affairs Branch officers for the proposed building lies between the existing Kathery School on the east and the agency office building on the west. It is bounded on the north by the Montreal-Melune New York Railroad and on the south by the remnants of the masonry walls of old Fort St. Louis. The area is sufficient for the demands of the proposed building, but is part of a solid rock formation having a shallow covering of sandy soil; boulders and outcroppings of rock are visible at points. The proposed building will require excavation for partial basement, septic tank and water supply, and it is considered that construction on the site selected would prove an expensive undertaking. The village has no sewage disposal system or water supply, and those services would have to be provided independently.

Sewage disposal could only be provided by tapping the sewer line installed at considerable expense about 1927, which carries sewage from the senior school to the St. Lawrence River. This sewer line is approximately 100 yards distant from the area where the new septic tank would be located, and the trench along with other excavation work would require blasting operations. It is estimated that in all site conditions would entail an additional expenditure of approximately $1000.00, raising the total cost of the building to approximately $8,750.00.

From an inspection of the quarters in the senior school where weaving and artcraft work is carried on, it was observed that the equipment was crowded and that storage space for unworked materials and finished articles was insufficient. Under existing conditions no display of articles for sale appears possible.

There is no building in the village which, even by remodelling, is considered adaptable to the needs of the Department.

On inspecting the Bush school and teacher's residence, they were found to be frame buildings erected approximately 40 years ago. They are located approximately 4-1/2 miles outside of the village, and will no longer be used.

Examination of the material with which the two buildings have been constructed, indicated that structural material such as joists and rafters are in good condition and could be re-used. Doubtless much of the wall and partition studding is also in good condition, but it could not be seen. No siding, shiplap, flooring or roof-boarding could be re-used. These materials are aged and weathered and would not resist dismantling.

Windows have...
Windows have only the lower sash fitted for pulleys, and the sash and frames would not be satisfactory for re-use. The exterior doors are in poor condition, and interior doors, with two exceptions, are too small for general use in the proposed new building. Before an accurate estimate of the amount or value of material for re-use could be obtained, the buildings should be dismantled and the materials inspected. Under the most favourable conditions however, salvaged materials would only constitute a small part of what would be required for new construction, and it is considered would not reduce costs by more than $500.00.

On the basis of the foregoing, it is recommended that:

(a) The Indian Affairs Branch officers give serious consideration to an alternative site for the proposed new building, which would materially reduce the cost.

(b) In order to prevent destruction by vandals or fire, the Bush school and teacher's residence be dismantled, and the material stored under cover until disposed of.

(c) That provided authority for construction of the proposed new building is granted, work should be carried out on a contract basis, setting a time limit for completion, and stipulating that parties tendering on the project shall make allowance for salvaged material on hand.

Respectfully submitted,

T.S. Mills

Dear Mr. Phelan:

In response to your request, I have been trying to find you a suitable teacher for the bush school of the Caughnawaga Reserve. Thus far, I am sorry to say, I have been unsuccessful.

There is a real shortage of teachers. In former years, there was a waiting list in Montreal; but now we are forced to use student-teachers and recently married teachers for supply work.

I have communicated with one of the regional inspectors, who has promised to get in touch with his district inspectors. I have asked him to get the name of any suitable teacher in the vicinity of Huntingdon or Valleyfield, where there would ordinarily be a small number of English-speaking teachers available.

I will continue to try and I will let you know the result of my inquiry as soon as possible.

Yours truly,

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill

Re: Building Inspection, Caughnawaga.

I have discussed with Mr. Mills, Chief Engineer, and Mr. Buck, our Architect, the possibility of the latter making an inspection at the earliest possible date, of the stone house that would be available through purchase, for a handicraft building, providing it was reasonably suitable.

Our Architectural staff is so depleted that Mr. Buck has only one Architect with him, and who was recently recalled to help with urgent architectural work, which includes a fish hatchery building to be constructed this fall and early winter in Jasper Park. As you know, Mr. Buck was away the greater part of last week, on the inspection of the Doctor's residence at Brantford, which was gutted by fire. In order that there may be no undue delay on this matter, he must complete certain sketch drawings before he again leaves the office. He must also leave the preparation of bills of materials for the refrigerating plant at Norway House, and the specifications for the refrigerating plant at Kamloops Indian School, at a stage where progress can be made on these while he is away. Consequently, he will not be able to leave for Caughnawaga before the latter part of next week. I hope to advise you definitely a week from today, so that your Indian Agent will have sufficient notice of the date of Mr. Buck's visit. Even this date will involve the postponement of work on two other projects which have been outstanding for some time.
Apart from preparing plans, bills of materials, and specifications for specific projects, Mr. Buck has to deal daily with verbal inquiries on various matters, some of which, as you will appreciate, take a good deal of time.

It is unfortunate that because of shortage of staff, we cannot deal more promptly with requests from different sources, relative to engineering and architectural matters, and I consider from the viewpoint of the interests of the Department, our architectural staff is now inadequate.

I am forwarding a copy of this memorandum to the Deputy Minister for his information.

Director.

My Dear Miss Moodie:

You are not without knowing about the terrible trial that befell Caughnawaga on the night of December 18. We haven't overcome the shock as yet. In fact, I and all the sisters are heart-broken.

This letter is to tell you that practically all your equipment has gone down in the fire. The only things saved are the pieces of woven goods which were in the show-cases and in the drawers of the cupboard.

We are now endeavoring to plan our work for the next school term but I am wondering what is expected of Sr. M. George. Will she continue in a Weaving Department? In fact, I would appreciate your personal visit very much for then it would be so much easier to discuss matters. May we expect one and soon? I am anxiously awaiting your answer.

Respectfully yours,

Miss Kathleen Moodie,
Ottawa.

Reverend and dear Mother:

The Bush School on the Caughnawaga Reserve is situated a few miles outside the village. Owing to difficulty in getting a teacher who is able to control the pupils we did not re-open this school on October 1. At one time we contemplated bringing the children to the Village School. However, in view of the recent destruction by fire of the senior school strong representations have been made to us to re-open the Bush School.

I understand from the Indian Agent that arrangements can be made to have the road ploughed from the village to the Bush School.

It would be appreciated by this Branch if you could arrange to have a member of your Order teach this school for the balance of the academic year. In view of the fact that we could arrange to have the road to the school cleared I thought it might be possible to have a Reverend Sister in charge of this school as she could be driven to the school each morning and brought back to the village residence in the evening. I should be glad if you would give this matter your immediate consideration and I trust that you will find it possible to let us have a favourable reply. We would be prepared to allow salary at the rate of $80.00 a teaching month plus the cost-of-living bonus of 11%. Of course you understand that from the amount just stated the National Defence Tax would be deducted.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

Your letter of January 28th reached my address while I was in Quebec. Since my return, I have tried once more to find you a teacher for the Bush School of Caughnawaga. I regret to say that I have been unsuccessful.

As I told Mr. Phelan in my letter of November 21st, there is a real shortage of English-speaking teachers in Montreal. Those who did not have permanent positions have sought and obtained employment elsewhere.

In any case, those who would ordinarily be available in Montreal would not be suitable for your need. They would probably be young teachers without sufficient experience.

I agree with the opinion expressed by Mr. Phelan in his first letter, namely, that the teachers who have been employed in the Bush School in recent years have been too young and have lacked experience. I should like to find you a teacher with some few years' experience in rural schools.

For this reason, I asked some of my colleagues of the rural districts to find me a teacher. Thus far, they have not been able to do so. As you probably know, there are few English-speaking schools in the rural sections of Quebec. For this reason and because of the low salaries in the rural schools, very few girls in these districts become teachers. Those who do qualify for teaching try to place themselves in the larger centres.

If you should decide to wait until next September to reopen the school, I may be able to find you a suitable person. It would be preferable to offer the teacher a contract to be signed on June 1st, as it is at that time that engagements...
are made for the following school year. I have in mind a certain teacher, a widow, who has several years of successful teaching to her credit. I am not sure that I can get her, of course; but it may be possible if I can give her definite assurance before June 1st. If neither the School Corporation nor the teacher gives notice before that date, the teacher's engagement is automatically renewed for the following year. If this particular teacher should not be available, she may be able to help me to find another suitable person.

Yours truly,

A. E. Wescott,
Inspector of Schools.

Dear Sir:

It is some time since I received your last letter on the subject of the re-opening of the Caughnawaga Bush School for the academic year 1942-43. I want you to know that I have not been inactive. However, I must confess that it is rather difficult to persuade a teacher of the right type to come in from outside and live in this lonely part of the Reserve.

After studying the question from every angle and investigating local conditions, I came to the conclusion that it would be better to have a teacher who would be experienced in Indian schools. I decided to interview Mrs. John Bush (Mary Stacey) of Caughnawaga. You will remember that she taught in your schools for some eighteen years. She resigned last year after her marriage. I asked her if she would be willing to teach in the Bush School next year, if your Department would consider it advisable to waive the rule against the engagement of married female teachers.

Naturally, I was not authorized to tell her that she would be engaged; but I told her that I would write to you and that I would ask you if it would be possible to depart from the usual policy of the Department regarding the engagement of married women. I respectfully suggest that you waive your general rule in the present instance. It is my considered opinion that this person will be able to handle the difficult situation in this school district better than any outsider and better even than an unmarried person at the present time. Mrs. Bush and her husband are very well respected on the Reserve. From confidential information which I obtained, I should judge that their moral life is above reproach.

If your reply is favourable, I shall immediately inform Mrs. Bush and ask her to make formal application
for the position. For your information, I may say that I told the lady that the salary offered would be $80.00 per month plus cost of living bonus for nine months.

While I was in Caughnawaga, I visited the site of the school. I could not enter the teacher's residence as it was locked. From what I could see through the window, the interior seems to be in good condition. It is unfurnished at present. I presume that you will furnish what is reasonably necessary as you do elsewhere. The interior of the schoolhouse should be painted and the desks varnished.

Please let me know your decision at your earliest convenience. This suggestion is made in the belief that it is the most practical solution of the peculiar problem of the Bush school district. It may be made clear to all concerned, including the people of Caughnawaga, that this is a wartime expedient and not a precedent. If, however, you do not find it possible to accept this suggestion, I will do my best to find you a teacher from outside.

Yours truly,

A. E. Wescott,
Inspector of Schools.

Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, 11th September, 1905

The Deputy Superintendent General:

With reference to the Resolution of the Caughnawaga Band of the 3rd March last for the establishment of additional schools on their reserve outside the village, I beg to say that as instructed by you I visited the Caughnawaga reserve and on Thursday, the 31st ultimo, in company with the missionary, Rev. Father Melancon, and Mr Delisle, teacher of the boys school, I drove over the eastern portion of the reserve, where there are 30 heads of families living all engaged in farming, who have children of school age to the number of 56 who, under the present school arrangements are unable to receive any education, all the schools being situated too far for the children to attend. This settlement is quite compact and we were able to find an empty house which with a small outlay could be made suitable for a temporary school. It could be had for the repairs and if the Indians would furnish the material they could do the necessary work. The building is 25 ft. by 13 ft. and would need to be sheeted inside and re-clapboarded for about half the dimensions and supplied with four new sashes. There is plenty of wood in the neighborhood and the Indians would furnish the necessary supply for the winter. It seems to me that it would cost about $75 to equip the school.

Mrs Beauvais, the assistant teacher at the Girls school is quite willing to take charge, provided
she is paid at the rate of $300.00 per annum, her present salary being $250.00.

There is another vacant house in good repair quite convenient to the school site mentioned, which could be utilized as a residence for Mrs Beauvais and her family. I am quite of opinion that it would only be fair to these Indians to give them another school. They are all permanent residents in the locality mentioned and remain at home with their families all the year round. The heads of the families, a large number of whom I met, expressed their desire to have their children educated and guaranteed a good attendance and said that if the attendance did not prove satisfactory, they were willing to have the school closed.

This is the most suitable place on the reserve for the establishment of a new school, should the Department decide to give them another one, as there are only a few Indian farmers on the other portions, whose children are near enough to attend white schools. From what I saw of these Indian farmers I think the Department would be quite justified in making the experiment if funds can be found.
