Ottawa, June 12, 1907.

The Deputy Superintendent General,

A petition has been received from the members of the Caughnawaga band living outside the village for the erection of a school-house in the school section lately established. This school was started last fall in temporary quarters with an enrolment of 38 pupils. Last quarter they had an enrolment of 44 with an average attendance of 31. The average attendance for the nine months has been about 30.

This school is certainly doing good work and should be encouraged. A letter has been received from Agent Blain stating that the Indians are willing to grant two or three arpents for a school site and a suitable school building is badly needed, as the present one is a mere shell without any proper accommodation for the teacher who has to reside on the premises.

Before this school was opened the children in this neighborhood had no opportunity of receiving any education, as they are too far distant from the village to attend any of the schools there, and if the Department wants to continue the good work now carried on it will have to provide a new school building and accommodation for the teacher. If the Department could afford it, I would suggest that a school-house and residence should be put up, as a teacher would be much more inclined to stay on permanently if a suitable home were provided. I do not think that this suggestion would cost much more than one large combined building and there will be plenty of available ground for both houses. Mrs. Beauvais, the teacher, informs me that unless something is done she does not see her way clear to remain another winter, as the present quarters over the school-room are so uncomfortable.

Re: Bush School on the Caughnawaga Reserve.

This school was opened last September as an experiment and has proved so successful (see Inspector Lippen's report) that the Department has decided to give them an up-to-date school building and teacher's residence and the choice of four locations has been offered.

Plans and specifications of the buildings have been prepared and the Department of Justice has furnished a draft quit claim conveying the land selected for the site to the Crown.

It will be necessary to choose a suitable site, have the deed executed and, before inserting the description, Mr. Bray suggests that the plot chosen be surveyed by the Surveyor now engaged in laying out the village. As the buildings will likely have to be put up by Indians, notice should be given at the Church door that the plans and specifications are ready for inspection by intending contractors. If this work were left to Mr. Agent Blain, there is no knowing when it would be attended to and I think someone should be sent from here to look after it, as the time for building is limited.

Referring to your letter of the 6th inst. re school site for the Bush settlement, Caughnawaga reserve, I beg to say that I have selected a very nice site indeed upon Lot 330, being the one offered by John Philips. Quit claim deed therefor is attached.

Philips was only willing to give 15,000 sq. feet but when he found that 30,000 sq. feet were required he very generously offered to grant 20,000 and sell another 10,000 for the nominal sum of $20.00.

The quit claim is drawn accordingly and if my selection is approved a cheque should issue in his favour at once to make his further agreement effective.

The site chosen furnishes good drainage and a nice aspect. It is close to the bank of a creek with sloping shores and a bottom some six or eight feet below the level of school site.

At the chosen site good water can easily be had. At the rejected site it is believed that it would be hard to obtain it.

The digging of a well should be arranged for.

As building sites there is no comparison whatever between the two offered. Lot 330 is so much better than Lot 312. Its location with reference to pupils homes is, too, far the best. Eleven children would be equally suited by either site. Lot 312 is nearer for 13 children and Lot 330 for 38 children.

From the selected site none of the 13 children

who live closer to the rejected site are further distant than 1 1/6 miles from the selected site, whilst from the rejected site some children are distant 2 miles. Average convenience is unquestionably best served by the selected site.

Both of these tenders are far in excess of the amount voted and, if the Architect's estimate was correct, they are exorbitant.

This school is for the children of some 30 families living in what is known as the "Bush Settlement" on the reserve but outside of the village of Gough-nawaga, these children being too far away to attend the schools in the village. The families referred to having urged the establishment of the school, temporary arrangements were made for the use of an empty cottage, but this cottage has not to be given up. The school has been such a success that proper accommodation for the classes and for a teacher's residence is required. The site has been obtained - the greater part of it as a gift from a member of the band. The sum required is $20,000 or £15. The Indian owner gave $20,000 or £15 and took £20 for the remainder, so that only the school-house and teacher's residence have to be provided.

The band has not sufficient money to pay for the buildings, so a Parliamentary appropriation is being obtained.

Re repairs to be done to the foundations of the school at the Suzanne River.

Sir,

Regarding the repairs to be done at the foundation of the Suzanne River, in the reserve of Caughnawaga, Mr. Louis Delisle, whom I sent to make the said repairs, reports to me that, after having inspected the foundation in question, he says it is absolutely necessary that this foundation should be made over again completely on the north side. The reason of this is that when this foundation was made the first layer of stones was not imbedded in mortar. These repairs will incur an expenditure of over a hundred dollars. I request the authorization from the Department to have these repairs made as recommended by Mr. Delisle and I beg the Department to kindly give me a reply immediately.

Your obedient servant,

Sgd. J. M. Brosseau,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, May 18, 1920.

Memorandum:

Mr. Scott,

J.M. Brosseau, Indian Agent at Caughnawaga, reports that the foundation of the Suzanne River School is in need of repair, and states that when the foundation was built, the first layer of stones were not embedded in mortar which has caused the foundation to give way. He estimates the cost at $100.00. Will you please advise whether this work is to be done.

While in Caughnawaga last week I had an interview with Mr. Brosseau regarding the above mentioned matter, and beg to inform you that it will be necessary to expend at least an amount of $125.00 to put the foundation of this school in a permanent state of repair. I may add for your information that the building was erected some twelve years ago, and that it would be advisable to allow this work to be performed in order to prevent the building from further damage.
May 26th, 1920.

Sir—

Replying to your letter of the 3rd ultimo, I beg to inform you that I have recently visited the Bush School, on the Caughnawaga Indian Reserve, and to say that the foundation wall under the school need to be replastered with cement to the proportion of one of cement to one of sand, the joints have to be cleaned first; this would cost about $10.00 beside the framing of the air-hole and the window on the east side of the foundation wall, which would also cost about $10.00. That would be all required for the school building.

As to the teacher's residence, the foundation walls seem to be in good condition with the exception of the upper joint to be filled in with cement in order to prevent the frost into the cellar. I also consider that a partition is necessary in the cellar for its division into half of its size which would be ample for the teacher's use, so that the temperature higher would be kept higher. The approximate cost of work and to foundation walls and the partition would be $30.00. The annex to the teacher's residence, which is used as the summer kitchen, a size of 10 x 11 x 12 feet require to be lined with board inside and painted two coats, the approximate cost is $100.00. I beg to point out that because of the frost getting under two of the foundation wall corners of the teacher's residence, the plaster is falling in almost every rooms with the exception of the wooden ceiling into two rooms. It would not be advisable to replaster.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, May 9th, 1923.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 7th instant, regarding the repairs required to the school and teacher's residence in connection with the Bush school on the Caughnawaga Indian reserve.

In reply I beg to say that you may arrange for the repainting with cement of the foundation wall under the school, and for the framing of the air hole and windows on the east side of the foundation wall of the school.

Regarding the teacher's residence, you may have the upper joint of the foundation wall filled in with cement, in order to prevent frost entering the cellar. A partition or dividing wall may also be erected in the cellar, dividing it into two halves.

It is noted that the approximate cost of the work to the foundation walls and the erection of the partition would be approximately $50.00. In the purchase of any material for these repairs, competitive prices should be obtained, and the purchase made from the firm quoting the lowest price.

We have no funds available at the present time for the purpose of lining the inside of the annex to the teacher's residence, replastering the rooms, or putting in a new floor in the kitchen. These repairs will have to stand over for the present.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your four letters of the 15th instant, regarding the supplies required for the use of the Bush school on the Caughnawaga Reserve.

In reply I beg to say that you may arrange for the purchase, transportation and necessary labour in replacing 17 lengths of stove pipe.

You may also purchase 100 square feet of 1" board in order to make the necessary repairs to the coal bin, one of the out houses and a cover for the well. You may also purchase a chain and hook with the necessary nails for the making of a winch on the school well.

You may also arrange to have the blackboard repaired and painted.

The purchase of a kitchen stove for the use of the teacher's residence is approved, the approximate cost of which should not exceed your estimate, viz: $25.

It will be necessary, before making the purchase of the above equipment, to obtain competitive prices from a number of dealers, and the purchase in each case should be made from the dealer quoting you the lowest price.

Properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering the expenditure incurred in the purchase of the materials and for any labour employed. We note that the teacher's husband will do the necessary work in the repairs to the coal bin, out houses and cover of the well.

The above purchases and work should receive your early attention.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his inspection of the Caughnawaga Bush School, draws attention to the repairs required to the teacher's residence. He states that the foundation of the school has many cracks and should be repaired this fall, also that the plaster of the dwelling house requires repairing, as much of it has fallen off.

It is considered that these repairs could be carried out by Mr. Beauvais, the husband of the teacher, without expense to the Department. If, however, he is unable to do so, you may arrange to have the necessary repairs made to the foundation and to the plaster where required. Memorandum:

As requested I made an inspection, in company with Indian Agent Letourneau of the Bush School and Teachers' residence at Caughnawaga, and I beg to recommend that the following repairs be authorized in connection with these buildings,-

SCHOOL BUILDING.

A new concrete foundation 18' x 7' should be constructed underneath this building to replace the present one which is made of stone masonry and partly fallen down. The present shingled roof is rotten and should be replaced by one made of creosote cedar shingles, same as those used in the roofing of the Protestant School at Caughnawaga. The inside and outside of the building should be painted during next year's holidays. The cost of this work would not exceed $1,100.00.

TEACHERS' RESIDENCE.

The roof is entirely rotten and should be replaced by one made of creosote cedar shingles as mentioned for the school. The building should be painted inside and outside in the near future. The foundation is in need of repair. The outside closets for both buildings should be readjusted and provided with suitable foundation. The cost of this would be about $500.00.

I would suggest that the Agent be asked to prepare a specification and obtain competitive prices in a similar manner as was done for the St. Isidore road school.

DEPARTMENTAL ENGINEER.

Sir,

I beg to confirm the verbal arrangements made by Mr. Chene of this Department, and yourself concerning the repairs required to the Bush School and Teachers' residence on the Caughnawaga Reserve, when an inspection of these buildings was made in your company this week.

The following repairs should be carried out under the supervision of a reliable working foreman as economically as possible, and I would request that you make a frequent visit to the work in order to see that it is being properly carried out.

**SCHOOL BUILDINGS.**

A new concrete foundation 18" x 7' high is to be constructed underneath the building to replace the present one which is built of stone masonry.

The present shingle roof is to be demolished and replaced by a new one made of creosote cedar shingles, similar to those used for the roofing of the Protestant School at Caughnawaga.

The interior and the outside of the old building is to be cleaned and given one good coat of lead paint.

**TEACHERS' RESIDENCE.**

The shingle roof is to be taken down and replaced by one made of creosote cedar shingles as mentioned for the school building.

The present foundation of the building is to be repaired wherever necessary.

The whole of the building inside and outside is to be given one coat of paint.

The outside closets for the use of both
buildings are to be readjusted in place on cedar posts also to be painted.

It will be necessary that you prepare a list of the materials required for the above mentioned repairs and obtain competitive prices from local merchants and place the order with the dealer quoting the lowest price, with the exception of the painting material which will be ordered direct by the Department from the list of quantities which I would ask you to send me as early as convenient.

Kindly acknowledge receipt of this letter and the time sheets and books which are being sent you under separate cover.

An advance of the paying of wages will be sent you as soon as I am advised that the work is started.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Sir,

With further reference to your letter of the 12th ultimo concerning the repairs required to the Bush School and teacher's residence on the Caughnawaga Indian Reserve, I beg to inform you that Mr. O. Barbeau, a competent foreman, together with a few laborers have today started with this work. They are proceeding first with the excavation around the school building in order to make a new concrete foundation. In excavating at a depth of about two or three feet the water has somewhat interrupted the work and we expect that it will be a difficult task to have this excavation well drained for the foundation which we intend to make at a depth of between three and four feet from the surface.

The foreman suggests that a drain be made from the school foundation to the creek, a distance of about 150 feet, otherwise this foundation would be always exposed to deterioration. I have asked him to make an estimate of it, together with the cost of clay pipes, and this will be submitted to you by the end of this week.

MEMORANDUM:

As authorized I made an inspection of the repairs which have been lately carried out for the complete renovation of the Bush School and Teacher's residence while in Caughnawaga yesterday.

I found that these buildings have been put in a satisfactory state of repair in accordance with detailed letter of June 12, turned out hereunder.

Sir,

I have the honour to inform you that I have just visited the Bush School on the Caughnawaga Indian Reserve. I had the pleasure to observe several great improvements in the appearance of the 27 pupils present as well as the class room, etc., which are now kept very clean.

As the husband of the teacher is agreeable to maintain the fire and the cleaning of that school during the present school year at the conditions which were allowed by the Department to Mrs. Beauvais, during the past years I recommend that that grant which was, I believe, of $50.00 be granted to Mrs. Phillips. I also recommend that Mrs. Phillips be authorized to purchase about five cords of fire wood at $4.00 per cord for the lighting of the fire in the Bush School as well as for the teacher's residence.

I wish to inform you of the intention of the Beauharnois Electric Company to install a line of electric transmission which would start from their principal line to the neighborhood of the Bush School, a distance of about a mile and a half. I take this occasion to ask you if it would be the intention of the Department, seeing that this line would be constructed in the course of this Fall, to have the installation made at the same time at the Bush School and also at the teacher's residence.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) L. Letourneau,

Monsieur,

Je sollicite de vous informer que certaines réparations sont nécessaires à l'école Bush dans la réserve de Caughnawaga.

La clôture autour du terrain de cette école est maintenant en mauvais état et il n'est plus possible d'empêcher les animaux du voisinage d'y entrer. La longueur de cette clôture est de 1000 pieds par 4 pds. de hauteur en broche carrée. Il faudrait 50 piquets ainsi qu'une barrière en deux panneaux. J'estime à $85.00 le coût des matériaux ainsi que la main d'œuvre pour le renouvellement complet de cette clôture.

La couverture du puits de l'école est présentement en très mauvais état et une cause de danger pour les enfants. Il en coûterait 5.00 pour ce travail.

L'étable qui sert d'abri au cheval et à la vache de l'institutrice devrait aussi être réparée. Sa base est entièrement pourrie et à cause de cela n'est plus habitable pour ces animaux, plus particulièrement durant les saisons pluvieuses alors que l'eau pénètre sur le pont à une épaisseur d'environ un pied. J'estime que le coût de ces travaux y compris le ciment, madriers, poutres, transport de sable et gravier, ainsi que la main d'œuvre s'élèverait à $75.00.

Ainsi, le coût total des réparations à faire s'élèverait au coût total de $165.00 et j'en recommande l'approbation par le Département. Je recommande aussi que M.A.Robert, gardien des écoles ait la surveillance des travaux projetés, sujet cependant à l'inspection durant le cours des travaux.

Votre obéissant serviteur,

Agent des Indiens.

Sir,

I have to inform you that certain repairs are necessary at the Birch school at the Caughnawaga Reserve. The fence around that school ground is now in bad shape and it is no longer possible to stop the cattle of the neighbors from going over. The length of that fence is 1000 ft. and 4 feet in height and is squared wire. We would need 50 posts and a two door gate. I presume that the cost of material and labor for the renewal of this fence would amount to $85.00.

The cover over the school well is at present in very bad shape and a cause of danger for the children using that well and costs $5.00.

The stable which shelters the cows and horse of the school teacher should also be repaired. Its base is completely rotten and on that account cannot be used during rainy weather, nor in on rainy days and is often an foot deep over the floor. The cost of repairs, cement, planks, nails, transportation of sand and gravel, as well as labour would amount to $75.00.

Consequently the total cost of repairs to be done would amount to $165.00 and I recommend it be approved by the department. I also recommend that Mr. Robert school guardian be appointed to supervise the work, subject to inspection during the course of the work.
